hi everyone Anthony Pham tan oh here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review dark time sunshine a and X dark time sunshine is the hip hop duo of Cape Cowen hope I'm pronouncing that correctly he is the MC in the duo and Zavala the producer this is the follow-up to the 2010 album vessel and here they kind of continued their tradition if you can use the word tradition with a band that has such a small discography a tradition of creative beats and kind of a subdued rapping style paired with some pretty heady and and dense lyricism a lot early Aesop Rock before I go into this review I'm gonna say this is not a hip-hop album for everybody I mean surely anyone can listen to it but this is not one of those hip-hop LPS that that goes hard or really kind of shows any kind of major dark side or aggression or anything like that I actually think it's significantly less dark than their previous LP overall ANX even in its loudest and most hyped up moments is is a very introspective and and contemplative hip-hop album which may be exactly the kind of hip-hop albums one of you needs right now any fan of dark time sunshine is going to notice right off the bat that the production has has really changed not only in sound but in mood as well and people who are new to dark time sunshine - I think you're gonna find the production on this thing - at least kind of stick out to you maybe not be the most unique thing on the block but but definitely bring a kind of heavenly tone this help you for sure is not really the kind of sample heavy cluttered moody and and sometimes noisy soundscape that vessel was by contrast on a NX the production here is is much more dreamy smooth Spacey I would throw in the word sweet too and and maybe even call me there are loads of tuneful choruses on this thing for example the track can't wait which is one of the songs that kind of kicks this LP off has a really really strong synth melody just soaring over the chorus as do a lot of songs on here and the track valiant which is really one of my favourite tracks on here has just a myriad just a casserole of synth sounds and phrases layered on top of each other playing on this really really tight and and busy drum break there's a really dreamy vocal contribution from child actor on that track and she shows up later on the LP too and what I like about this song is that this thing has maybe the most synthesizer layers on it than any other track on the album but they are organized so methodically that it all kind of just makes sense and functions in harmony there are a couple other guest singers on this thing like on the tracks I'll be damned and never cry wolf and and honestly I find a lot of the singers on this LP to be really kind of weak when it comes to power behind their voice emotion behind their voice I mean the same song he chorus is on this LP really did nothing for me absolutely whatsoever I actually thought these particular tracks were kind of the low points on the album even if the production was good even if the lyrics and the verses were pretty good or profound but still these guest singers and all the synthesizers and and the lack of just moody sounds that make Vessel such a potent album this ANX is is so much more of a blissful move for dark times sunshine I mean it's really just kind of like a hip-hop dream which is fine because Kate Cowan actually acknowledges dreams as being a pretty big influence or maybe not an influence but a great way to find lyrical content because so much of his lyricism has like borderline surreal qualities to it now the rapping on this thing from him overall it's kind of monotone actually a little bit more monotone than he was on vessel I mean he's really shooting for something much more laid-back way more contemplatively you too you know Nash your teeth or moving your see or anything like that I mean really just kind of massage your mind even when he does manage to spit out something pretty fast which can be often because he does have a fast flow I mean there's a lot of technical ability to his rapping it's still pretty you know hmm I mean the only tracks on here that kind of stick out to me is not having a blissful feel to them are like rock off look at what the cat do which features bus driver and a song on here that really kind of reminds me of a song or two from vessel that had kind of a competitive feel to it because you had numerous emcees on it take my hand which features suam burger and Aesop Rock you know and I do have to admit I do enjoy the darker and more gritty side of dark time sunshine the constant sonic ecstasy of a and X does kind of bore me a little bit does get a little mundane but I still acknowledge that that dark time sunshine does it really well I mean they've made a great transition they have really kind of made a 180 with the mood of their music in a lot of ways and and have done it to the point where it doesn't feel like a huge letdown I'm sure for a lot of fans it's it's kind of an improvement an exciting progression to kind of touch upon the lyrics and the subject matters of these tracks one of the songs that opens this LP up can't wait kind of talks about the progress of dark times sunshine and just like I don't know the the travel of their music of their kind of musical journey there's a line in here about wrapping it or just basically making music until the coffins dropping to me this track kind of actually feels like a letter to the listeners kind of maybe assuring them of what this album is gonna be where dark times sunshine is going to go how devoted they are to this vision to this direction the track cult class kind of takes a religious point of view or maybe not religious point of view but maybe kind of just like a fantasy religious point of view talking about getting on a rocket ship paid for by money from the church's collection plate and then going to heaven on it and they're talking about Apple employees being apostles I mean there's a lot of surreal imagery on on this thing but not necessarily I guess some kind of strong theme or message or point to what is being said at least to me anyway Rochester AP comes in on one of the verses later in the track and he just really is awesome on his verse I mean all the guest rappers on this album are great to be honest and there is space imagery in in his lyrics mentions of Dreams at this point you're kind of seeing the recurring themes in the track rock off dreams come up again where there's there's like more meta conversation going on in the lyrics with Kate Cowen mentioning that you know he uses dreams as an inspiration and then mentions how you know he took all these ideas from them and then wrote a track from their previous album and the track I'll be damned kind of feels like a self-improvement track just really kind of has this this feel of striving wanting to get better there's a great line on here about the art of storytelling that you've got to hear if you give a listen to this album the track take my hand that I mentioned earlier is just 100% lyrical fire with swamp burger and Aesop Rock on there and I actually think ASAP rocks verse on that thing the third verse on this track is like the most brutal verse on the entire LP with the mention of death cards and the trick and just kind of like how death is on hold on the phone and that's great but kind of a downside is that not only his verse but a lot of the verses from the guest rappers on this LP grab my attention and impress me whether it be with with Flo or just concept so much more than what dark time sunshine has going on you know I did like this album a lot but there were just kind of like some some glaring not huge glaring but glaring nonetheless negatives for me just constant bliss a lot of hooks that I didn't really care for and I do think the bright flashy scents and and just heavenly production do kind of overshadow the wrapping at times especially considering how much more subdued the flows are on this LP in comparison with vessel which I foolishly did not review in 2010 they just kind of got a new direction here that I'm not agreeing with 100% but still a really solid left-field hip hop album that you should check if you claim to be a fan of this genre you know you know if you know kind of feeling a decent strong seven on this LP what did you guys think if you've given it a listen did you love it hate it why and what should I review next anthony Fantana dark time sunshine forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantan oh here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's a time to just sort of give some name drops give some mentions to what have been my favorite albums of this past month the month of sep tember my most recent super positive review was given to the new gaslamp killer LP breakthrough really in album to me that is a celebration of just the psychedelic and experimental beat music scene going on California right now in LA specifically not only does the gaslamp killer up his production chops for this LP but he brings on numerous artists who come from this style to kind of help him make this album the extremely colorful textured moody and diverse record that it is next i bet on sky the new dinosaur jr LP here dinosaur jr. basically does what they do as well as they have ever done it lots of very catchy kind of wimpy and whiny but a motive and and moving indie rock tunes with a lot of volumes very strong a lot of guitar solos that are just breathtaking awesome and some solid songwriting to next what I think is probably my favorite album of this entire month the new on the throw pika LP this is a self-titled album from a Colombian cumbia supergroup with a rotating cast of over 40 musicians playing on this thing some of them old Latin music veterans some of them new bright young minds who are experimenting with the genre bringing in elements of hip-hop and rock music electronic music as well and just all these flavors from Scott music to Middle Eastern music kind of come in and influence these vintage Latin sounds however the fact that they all play very well and they have a very strong Latin music foundation really pulls everything together and makes this album consistent despite the fact that it is genre wise and influence wise kind of jumping around all over the place it's just a fantastic album with a lot of great playing great improvisation and just enough change and and just enough again variety among these 20 or so tracks that are on this album to make the hour plus length that it lasts entertaining and engaging another LP i love this month the new corrales album years past matter this is a progressive rock album that uses the tremolo guitar playing the vocals and just the overall aesthetic of black metal to kind of bring these very tightly wound complex and and dizzying guitar compositions that go ten-plus minutes on a lot of tracks here I mean it is it is not a light listen it's very challenging it's very dense and it's really something that it took a while for me to kind of get through but once I got through it was just like dark tortured ecstasy yeah and as long as we're on the subject of dark and tortured the new murder construct album that came out this this year is freaking awesome if you're looking for a solid technically proficient and very methodical grindcore record that has some fantastic vocals from Travis Ryan of the band cattle decapitation he really just brings some hellish vocals on this thing the drums are very detailed they're all over the place and there are some nice moments where the base kind of steps out and does something melodic to on this album I mean it is an intense record it is just a brutal record not something that I think is necessarily going to step out and kind of pull in people who are not necessarily fans of grindcore already but still very solid and enjoyable album for this style alright those are those are the album's I am recommending for this past month of September let me know what you're you know enjoy recently you know what records did you love this month and and that's it you know that is it Anthony Fantana music recommendations forever you

ah hey y'all Anthony Fantino here Internet's scratchy throat music nerd and it's time for a review Lupe Fiasco food and liquor to the great American rap album part 1 Lupe Fiasco is a Chicago rapper who made a pretty nice entry into the hip hop industry with a debut album that was lauda Daz just one of the best hip hop albums of 2006 this album was filled with catchy emotive production from the likes of Kanye West's soundtrack The Neptunes even Linkin Park's Mike Shinoda produced a track for this thing and of course movie brought maybe what he is best known for his very sharp thought-provoking lyricism with a very socially conscious edge it was just awesome to see somebody so high up in the hip hop industry with hit singles like kick push and daydreaming but also had kind of a refreshing perspective you know wasn't rapping about the same stuff that everybody else was now the very next year Lupe put out another LP the cool this album featured way more production from soundtrack Lupe lyrically was getting a bit more bold a bit more maybe preachy in a sense and he took a more conceptual route with the overall theme of the album and I feel like his more topical tracks on this LP were way more pointed like the song hip hop saved my life this LP is not as celebrated as food and liquor and of course there are reasons I mean it's not as immaculately produced you know definitely some questionable decisions I guess on this album but nobody saw what was coming down the pipe with what Lupe did last year with what was his latest album lasers the LP had a lot of pre-release drama the album's coming out a way it's not coming out then he claimed that his label made him make decisions that he wouldn't have made otherwise in regards to the hooks or the instrumentals no matter what the drama where the real story was what the end result was on on lasers was basically a socially conscious hip-hop album yes but with some very glitzy electronic and kind of sterile instrumentals that made Eminem's recovery look like it went as hard as Death Grips lyrically Lupe was still on point sure you know you couldn't really knock a lot of his messages on these tracks and and there were some decent singles on here like the pretty inspirational the show goes on but these pop beats are just too sweet on the ears not really representative of the urgency of some of the situations that Lupe was rapping about especially when you're getting these very bright loud auto-tune courses on the track beautiful lasers I mean that just really kind of made songs on here despite what Lupe was saying cut of unlistenable I kind of feel the same way about the track state-run radio I mean you know I could really agree with what a lot of Lupe is saying on here but you know I'm not into music for just the philosophy of it you know I mean I could totally agree with you and and that's cool you could be making a point that I am 100% behind but if it doesn't sound good I mean you know that I'm not liking it you know nothing against your ideology but I'm not liking your music and I feel like ever since the release of lasers Lupe has kind of been in the midst of damage control he put out the friend of the people mixtape shortly after the release of lasers and that mixtape ironically featured him rapping over more electronic beats which I previously thought were being forced upon him on lasers but now about a year later we have a new full-length album whose title evokes Lupe Fiasco's most celebrated album food and liquor specifically food and liquor two the great American rap album part one the part one is really there and I'm sure eventually we're going to get to Lupe Fiasco food and liquor too the great American rap album part two electric Boogaloo you know usually I could just totally give a she she she she she in terms of what the album title is with an LP but there's just so much pretense that comes with this title not only does the title imply that this LP is going to continue upon what made food and liquor great but the great American rap album part one well I feel like I can confidently say that this is not really a continuation of food and liquor and if it is it's it's really one of those movie sequels where 90% maybe 95% of everyone involved is like completely gone the lead role Lupe is still there but we've got different directors the love interest we remember from the last movie is like a completely different woman she was like a blonde in the first movie and now she's like a redhead and they're just kind of crossing the fingers and hoping that no notices and the fact that we do have a beat from soundtrack on on the second song here is really the only thing production wise that makes this album resemble food and liquor the biggest issue with this album and it continues to be an issue with Lupe is the production a lot of the instrumentals on this thing sound like they would have been popping behind gangsta rap club hits in the mid or early 2000s the beats on this thing with the exception of a few are just really forgettable bland and in kind of generic thin and just not a lot of punch not a lot of energy to them though they are not as bright or flashy or electronic as lasers I do think they're as poppy despite the fact that what a lot of Lupe is saying is real I feel like musically and instrumentally he sugarcoats it all the way I do like the soundtrack instrumental on strange fruition even though a lot of people kind of had some drama over the Pete Rock inspired sample on the track around my way and I don't really think that sample was executed in the most tasteful way possible I mean the beat is a little bland I do like the fact they are kind of tributing you know that era of hip-hop with that song and the instrumental behind the track cold war is pretty great too i like the the breathy vocal sample on there and jane totally just murders that hook was very powerful and passionate vocals but outside of that tracks like bitch bad I mean the instrumental on the thing just sounds so kind of cheap thrown together not really all that detail same thing with a track like Lamborghini angels I don't like that instrumental at all either and if there's one thing that disappoints as much as the instrumentals on this thing is the hooks like on the track it tau which kind of comes out right at the gate with this LP where Lupe Fiasco really says and some kisses for the babies like is he for serious I know the song has positive vibes it's well intended it's wishing the world were a better place it's optimistic its idealistic but could Lupe have maybe tried either instrumentally or or lyrically to make that idea sound maybe a little less corny than it actually is and when he's singing that hook later on the track with the auto-tune it just sounds terrible the track heart donor has a terrible hook as well and the song is unforgettable youth and battle scarves actually kind of sound like hooks that would make it onto an Eminem LP one of his new ones you know it's it's definitely not as shockingly bad as lasers but maybe that's only because the shock is kind of worn off at this point I mean if there's anything I can applaud on this album it's the lyrics I did like a lot of Lupe's lyrics on lasers but what kind of makes this help pay better than lasers is that you can actually hear them a lot of the time whereas the production on that last LP was was overshadowing hibbett points I do really like Lupe's verses on the track Lamborghini angels where he is throwing some really sharp and pointed criticisms at religion and I like the way how Lupe has three verses that tell kind of three sides to the story in the track pitch bed and then you just kind of ties them together at the end there are times when I do kind of feel like Lupe takes his point and he kind of just beats the listener over the head with it as opposed to being abstract maybe kind of letting people come to their own conclusions I'm not really sure how much further I can I can kind of go on with this album I mean I'm just going to keep running around in circles at this point if I talk anymore yeah I can keep praising and keep talking about lines that Lupe spits out in song concepts that he pulls together on this album the track hood now is great so is cold war so it was around my way lyrically but I'm just not liking the instrumentals on a majority of this album they really just kind of take the energy and the power out of a lot of what Lupe is saying I mean there is more urgency and and passion in the slam poetry on the track Ayesha says that kicks this album off then a lot of these songs with Lupe rapping over these weak instrumentals so again I don't really disagree with a lot of Lupe's points and I like that he's you know spreading this message and giving it to his listeners and a lot of them take it seriously but I mean me instrumentally and maybe even philosophically too I'm just going to kind of hang with the league of great socially conscious rappers to come before Lupe most def telling quali black star Boogie Down Productions A Tribe Called Quest Public Enemy the roots common and despite the fact that a lot of those artists are older you know let's be honest a lot of the problems that they rapped about are still kind of problems so to be completely honest I'm really feeling a strong four to a light five on this album definitely improvement over lasers but Lube eight really needs to get back to picking some good production did you love this LP did you hate it why and what should I review next anthony Fantana Lupe Fiasco food and liquor - forever [Music] [Music]

collage just like nothing but crate Doug magic kind of overlapping fed through this psychedelic fog it really kind of sets a dark weird mad-scientist assemble tone for the album go Andrew Sufi kind of does his thing on the next track over a string sample not an incredibly developed track but it does kind of get the flavor out there you know there are quite a few moments on here that do not feel one idea to the next and I'm not necessarily against a one or two minute motif or or B or anything like that as long as the artist can make something impactful or moving or memorable meaningful within the short amount of time that they've given themselves I really dig the track holy Mount Washington which has these really just loud pounding sharp crisp drums backed up with these just very eerie string shots and then kind of a strange whistle really kind of hanging in the ambiance in the background I like the juxtaposition of the instruments on this track it's really like just some bitter and moody ear candy the gasps I'm Keller brings on some guests for the track dead vets which is like some psychedelic hip-hop infused funk but things get really layered and complex and detailed on the track flange face with with Michael Atwood Ferguson where you have the Gaslamp Killer delivering these just heavy drums synthetic distorted muck with some synthesizers and Ferguson just lays on these wonderful strings that have kind of a middle-eastern quality to them but at times they they kind of start dripping down the wall like droplets of blood in a horror movie that's one of the longer tracks on the album and it's kind of epic peaks like that that really in my eyes justify the smaller and shorter moments it's like you kind of have these well develop giants and then these you know shorter little morsels and bits hanging around them maybe buzzing around them like flies it gives the album an interesting flow a disjointed but but interesting flow there's always just kind of like a surprise turn about to happen and I like that the track he does with Daedalus is another darken and moody number and I love the really bouncy keyboard arpeggios that that come off that they sound like they almost have kind of like an 8-bit quality to them or something like that me then there's just something videogame about them and if another dependent I love the two tracks that close this thing out seven years of bad luck for fun is a great track really glitchy really tortured and the closer in the dark goes six minutes and stays engaging throughout I mean it's really climactic finish for um of knapsack of hot water music maybe you could even like in some of the rips to Nirvana some of the really strong melodic guitar playing to Dinosaur Jr and and some of the shots of noisy feedback filled distortion to Sonic Youth the thing is to me this album is just pretty much like a Frankenstein monster of all of the records that kind of drove title fight to make this record and you know the thing is whose music isn't that to an extent sure I can see that what kind of bugs me with with title fight though is that I can really kind of see the seams of what they've sewn together the ideas and the influences on this album aren't really melted together with a bit of title fights own signature personality kind of thrown into to make it their own thing and the only reason I really feel that way is because when it came time to really kind of write this review after listening to this album again and again I was writing and thinking well their music is influenced by a B C and D but and the chords are just the bomb on this track just in a that's like the way the guitars are being played is just so blood pumping right after that track the song head in the ceiling fan is is much slower much more emotive and and really one of my favorite tracks on the LP it's the first spot on the album where things just really slowed down and when I say slow down I mean like they are going like half speed like quarter speed in comparison with the other tracks and it sounds great at this point on the album I would actually say title fight sounds kind of blissful and here it becomes very obvious hi everyone Anthony Fantana here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new how to dress well LP total loss to my right your left we can see couchy chesta dressed in one of the finest polo shirts known to man coming straight from the Anthony Fan Tan Oh dresses like a total nerd collection and has no fashion sense whatsoever which is most likely why he wears graphic tees all the time we can also see him adorned in a beautiful little sweater vest right there wonderful our guy'll pattern which is getting messed up in green screen a little bit but you know that's that's the way the cookie crumbles I just said that how to dress well is the project of singer and producer Tom Krell who made quite the polarizing full-length debut with the album love remains which he kind of built up to with a series of EPs and this LP was was really great at just gathering attention because of the unique musical and and stylistic approach it had just incredibly low fire recordings of falsetto vocals slathered and reverb singing over beats and a very very clear R&B influence coming through on almost everything he was doing the album was just dark and murky and and moody it was like listening to prints going through a severe depression and I did really liked his style and in a lot of ways you could say that this dude was ahead of the curve when it comes to all the experimental and and forward-thinking R&B wvwv artists that are out there right now but I did not like the recording quality at all I like the style I like the direction I continued to keep my ear to the ground with this project I was very impressed with the EP that was released shortly after this album would which had orchestral versions of the suicide drain tracks that love remains album that sounded beautiful also last year how to dress well was featured on one of my favorite singles of 2011 active child's playing house the track was just smooth atmospheric slow-motion R&B with just sexy as hell vocals lush and glistening instrumentation with synthesizers that had kind of a retro feel to them you know if he could pull off something like that I know I would like his next album and with total loss lo and behold we do get a better recorded and in a lot of ways more realized version of how to dress well not only that but the moods between this LP and and love remains are almost night and day love remains being much more noisy experimental in just dark while this has a really kind of heavenly quality to it there's still a really strong R&B influence I would argue that maybe it comes out even stronger in a popular fashion on some of these tracks but the atmosphere the ethereal atmosphere surrounding the instrumentation on these songs sometimes even has like a new-age music quality to them overall sonically this is definitely an improvement for how to dress well but I kind of feel like these improvements do come with their own set of cons even with the massive amounts of reverb on some tracks here there are just no veils to hide behind on total loss which is kind of making me re-evaluate how I feel about the music and the vocals now that I feel like I'm getting a full picture of them and I got to say sometimes the music sometimes the vocals they are on and they are off when how to dress well is on fire it's on the track cold nights I love the distance synthesizers just hidden in the atmosphere on that track they're really dramatic piano and the and the lumbering beat but now that I hear Krauss voice just front and center it kind of exposes that the falsetto that he always sings and doesn't really have a natural grace to it or anything like that I mean I pick up a lot of points where he is straining and consistently I don't really think he has all that much power volume wise when it comes to singing with this falsetto there's no real force behind it still that doesn't keep cold nights from being a great track for me mostly because there are other things to hear and focus on later on the LP and it was you just has Crowell singing raw over these looped finger snaps and you just really just hear his voice that's it he's singing with a bit more energy just a bit more get up and go but he still kind of ends up coming off like a shy Michael Jackson impersonator I don't know if that appeals to you but it's not necessarily for me I could see what he's going for but it's just not really moving me so there are songs on here like fully realized songs that do feel a little underwhelming but there are tracks that feel to me even more forgettable that don't really have all that much structure to them at all overall on this LP the songs are longer you're not really getting those tracks that dip underneath two minutes like you would have on love remains you know those tracks that would kind of sound like a motif or an idea but they wouldn't last too long so they sounded fine they sounded great kind of swimming around in the murk of the other tracks but this time around you still get motif tracks but they last three minutes four minutes and they tend to kind of get mundane like on the track say my name or whatever where Tom Krell is kind of vocalizing over these sparkling loops that just continue throughout the entire track and it gets kind of old fast just because of a lack of progression same with the track running back which I think has a great intro a nice smooth bass line some fluttering guitars too but some of the loops just get there just a lot of tracks on here that I felt could have used more progression more climaxes to stay engaging if Tom Krell was going to repeat himself ad nauseam like this I mean the music and his voice would have to be a bit more stunningly beautiful maybe it's that way for you but but maybe hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's review time David Byrne and saint vincent love this giant this is a collaborative album collaborate collaborate on music collaborate collaborate music a collaborative LP from David Byrne and saint vincent great musical artists each of them in their own right you could say two of modern music's most eccentric characters this is assistant I mean they're both out there but I wouldn't necessarily say they're both cut from the same stylistic cloth you know once their creative juices mixed what would the end result be that was ultimately my question would it be some kind of strange Talking Heads bush of ghosts everything that happens strange mercy actor Frankenstein monster of sounds but David and Annie completely sidestepped all of that stuff now a letter about this album released and written by David Byrne along with the first track to drop from this LP who revealed that the challenge that David and Annie were facing on on this LP was horns an entire album of songs heavily dependent on arranged horn sections and the first track to drop from this thing who kept excitement and expectations high the track had kind of a herky-jerky groove to it something I would expect David to kind of bring to the table farty colorful and and zany horns playing some pretty complex arrangements you've got David Byrne and Annie Clark singing together trading off vocals spots it was kind of a dream collaboration but I can't help but feel like this thing was ever so slightly a little bit like a little baby letdown horns they really labored over these horns on every track and there is no 1 track you know singling out saying oh this is very you know a nice densely layered horn piece that that's very busy I mean personality from the horns it's a track that really kind of throws inhibitions out the window but on the other side of the spectrum there are a lot of arrangements on here that are very beautiful very tender kind of touching especially the introductions to the tracks dinner for two and an ice age and the entirety of the closing track outside of space and time which kind of almost has like a musical theater quality to it or like a Disney soundtrack as you first listen to this LP like it happened to me you're most likely going to just have your attention grabbed by the horns you're not going to hear anything else you're not gonna hear the songwriting a lot of which is great and just kind of be distracted by how flashy and and kind of gaudy these horns can be it's rare to listen to an LP with what even though some of these songs are structured the same they do have those horns that are prevalent on every track there is a lot of topical variety on this LP volume variety emotional variety where my disappointment my huge disappointment that literally ruins some songs on this album for me my big disappointment where it comes in is in the other instrumentation mostly the drum machines on this thing hearing drum machines paired with really lush gargantuan horns sections is is not really a combo I like especially considering a lot of the rhythms on this thing do tend to fall flat and and suck the viscera right out of a lot of these tracks weekend in the dust dinner for two Lazarus an ice age to I'm either just not digging the beats they get too repetitive or the Timbers on them and epic where Dan loses me is is on a track like crash Jam the electronics on this thing are fuzzed out as usual but to kind of add insult to injury for me on this track he throws all of the least interesting sounds into the foreground and buries all of the better sounds underneath than the vocals the drums the chords the first half of this LP was kind of hit or miss for me the second half is is like a completely different section of the album it is basically a group of tracks creating a suite that is titled after this album and I'll be damned if the first movement of this thing USA is a monster which maybe a statement or maybe a reference to the band of the same name either way to me this is really one of the best tracks I've ever heard dandy can make there is an awesome orchestral intro on the song that should stop anybody in their tracks who's listening to this thing all the way through the electronic glitches and and distortions that Dan usually works with eventually make their way into the track but they don't overstay their welcome and as the song continues they kind of get blended with that nice sounding orchestral instrumentation I like that combo overall the song does not feel as just obnoxious or annoying or as overbearing as some of his more electronic tracks can like the next song on this week the great American desert eventually the song ended up kind of sounding exactly like that just a desert a barren wasteland of just static that I'm not interested in hearing however the song rail right after is just completely orchestral instrumentation totally barren of electronics and it is lovely and it's just a great show of how Dan Deacon understands interplay and in counterpoint and when you can actually hear it on the closing track you have electronics mixed with a pretty epic gargantuan chorus but the electronics just kind of come to the forefront and drown the chorus out I mean why the electronics aren't even that interesting especially this point in the album when they are pretty much doling out the same exact sounds and Tambor's that you've been hearing for the entire album overall I got to say I'm torn on this album there was a handful of songs on here that I felt like wow I mean some of the best material I've ever heard Dan Deacon put out I love it when he's just working with normal orchestral instrumentation and maybe it would even sound great with him mixing it with the electronics if he had just more of a balance and not really one suffocating the other but as you guys know that's just my opinion I'm feeling a strong 5 on this LP if you guys give it a listen what did you think about it love it hate it why what should I review next and remember the good comment the great rate only the strong subscribe dan deacon America forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for you review yen's Luqman I know what love isn't it's pretty avant-garde this is the third full-length album from this dude I believe it is the first LP in five years from the Swedish singer-songwriter and it's the follow-up to the reasonably celebrated night falls over courted alla a pretty elaborate and eccentric baroque pop LP loaded with colorful instrumentation and sounds and and lovely songs I'm talking horn and string flourishes harp piano glockenspiel as well as some scents and electronics and dance beats on this thing as well it's an album that's really kind of all over the place but yen's with his very lovestruck personality he's just kind of strong enough to pull it all together and just make it feel for the most part cohesive plus the LP was was a very important part of his artistic evolution because his debut album was someone was someone was just soaked in this painfully obvious magnetic fields influence which was cool but he really kind of came into his own on this LP and on this latest album there's still no question that yen's is is still doing his own thing and I feel like I'm I know what love isn't he definitely meets expectations but kind of manages to do it with less than his previous album less material less eccentricity less color instrumentation stuff like piano and strings and background vocals are still on this album but for the most part these songs really do kind of stick to those singer-songwriter roots of bass drums guitar and vocals and if I do have an issue with the instrumentation or the production overall on this album it's that the sounds just the the playing it can be a little too PG sometimes if you know what I'm saying like it's a little tone down and yet it also has this extremely happy cheery feel to it like I could totally hear the sound tracking me prancing gleefully down Sesame Street or something like that the instrumentation gets especially weird on the tracks you just don't want to be with you anymore where man this is just like some celine dion my heart will go on pan flute types at times i do kind of wish the melodies and and the tempo of these tracks matched up a little bit logically with the heartbreak and the emotional confusion that Yin's is going through on the stories with a lot of these tracks but still for the most part what you're gonna hear on this album is going to induce some very good mood vibes even if they are kind of a bit cloying at times is it too late to mention that sometimes the melodies the chord progressions the arrangements are a little too tried and true to be feeling all that fresh or amazing the real meat on this album comes from yen's himself his songwriting his singing his lyrics just his personality and how he consistently stays on the topics of love and and heartbreak still he brings the kind of charisma and poetic genius and hilarious musings and and unique perspectives that kind of make listening to stuff like this worth it all over again and that's apparent right from the first track where Yin sings Erica America I wish I'd never met you like I wish I'd never tasted wine or tasted it from lips that weren't mine now every drop tastes more bitter all the time and right after that particular lyrical moment in the song this schmaltzy saxophone comes swaggering and despite the fact that there is a lot of heartbreak and just relationship issues on this album Yin's does have an incredible amount of swagger which is why I definitely do not hesitate in recommending this album to anybody who liked that destroyer LP that dropped last year even though this album is much less drenched in 80s chic the next track on here is a funny anecdote not a friend's love interest kind of saying that man I wish there was a pamphlet saying so you think you're in love with Jennifer and the track kind of goes on to compare being in a relationship to being owned by somebody and and and preferring being free and Yin's eventually kind of takes more comfort in sleeping on his own arm to the point where he loses feeling and it feels like someone else's arm even though this album does feel incredibly sappy sometimes there was a strong anti SAP sentiment in some of the lyrics like when he invites this girl out to go see a band and she says no I hate bands I hate shows they're just filled with guys who are desperately spooning their girlfriends as if when they let them go they just float away there's a lot of humor in this guy's tales and he tells many of them very nonchalantly just kind of throwing around the word some stories that Yin's works into his tracks or more impressive than others like the song the world moves on it's the longest song on the LP and kind of details in the verses all these little moments of heartbreak and how you never quite get over that but you just kind of work out ways to handle it gracefully another track on here that makes an interesting statement the end of the world is bigger than love kind of a weird angle for an album with so many love obsessed songs but it's a point that yen's still makes but their points in the track where I kind of feel like lyrically he digresses a little bit and that kind of happens in in in a lot of spots on this album kind of being entertained by his own ability to throw in some non sequitur while still delivering a relatively smooth ride the last track on the LP I love and has a strong theme though it's a track about being close with someone and that person eventually being gone but just the memory of them everything reminds you of that person or remembers that person from the chords on your guitar to the hairs on your body overall I thought this was a really good LP if you're in the market for a singer-songwriter who has a lot of charm a lot of wit and some sweet melodies as well this is definitely worth checking out I'm kind of feeling a decent too strong seven on this album what did you think of it you've given it a listen did you love it hate it why and what should I review next remember the good comment the great rate but only the strong subscribe Anthony Fantan Oh mr. Lachman forever

oh hi everyone Anthony Fantino here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review Animal Collective centipede hurts this is the latest LP from Sonic experimentalists Animal Collective their ninth full-length album I believe maybe not their ninth LP technically as Animal Collective but their ninth LP together as a group of musicians and if you've been paying relatively close attention to underground independent music for the past eight to five years you have probably heard of Animal Collective and know a bit about the reputation the 2000s brought a league of new sounds expressions and ideas to the world of psychedelic rock and pop just neo psychedelia and as far as this new breed of psychedelic artists go very few of them were as bold and as strange and as polarizing as Animal Collective with one album after another the band would deliver indescribable sound effects and an extreme use of the sound effects and studio trickery that we're already familiar with shouted vocals harmonized vocals weird angular melodies inspiration coming from numerous styles of music coming from around the world it's kind of difficult to do an overarching you know kind of picture a description of the band style because there is a noticeable shift in in sound on every animal collective release they've always brought some kind of evolution whether it's to the wild and noisy and abrasive here comes the Indian or the very kind of harmonious and stripped down and pretty song tongs or the very fun inspiring and colorful strawberry jam now their last full length album Merriweather Post Pavilion was their biggest success yet and an album that was by far their poppy esteem really took their usual abrasiveness and threw it out of the window one of the members panda bear who would usually you know split songwriting duties with another member of the band AV tare really kind of took the reins on that record as far as singing and songwriting and as far as production and presentation goes Merriweather Post Pavilion was definitely their biggest and in glossiest album ever it was still an animal collective album but very very groomed as groomed as you were gonna get them while still maintaining what makes them fundamentally them plus the album just had some really fantastic singles brother sport summertime clothes and of course what pretty much dominated all of 2009 and just blog ability and remix ability my girls this album just brought an immense amount of hype toward them and just internet harvested independent music in general this LP a lot of ways just marks a huge turning point not only for Animal Collective but for psychedelic music as well how we as listeners share and talked about music and in the blogosphere that writes about this music every day earlier this year the band dropped a new single which I gave a very positive review to and there was the announcement that Deacon a member of the band who kind of took a temporary leave during the time the band was making Merriweather Post Pavilion was now back plus you had the track today supernatural which dropped before the release of this album kind of promoting toward the release of this album gave it a review very positive review love the song still love this song and to me that track forecasted a much rahrr noisier and just more strawberry jam esque kind of album which I was excited for and got to an extent but I can't help but feel a bit disappointed by the end product and the main reason is that for sure just easily no question this is the first time I am picking up a new animal collective album and the band has not introduced me to anything new wildly different or done anything surprising with their progression or evolution and now that that gripe is out of the way my second biggest gripe on this album the production is pretty underwhelming Merriweather Post Pavilion was certainly like I said Animal Collective spa piaced release but going more experimental mean kind of scaling back the big gargantuan presentation and and the lushness of their sound and making things just more muddy more messy the vocal harmonies the animal collective puts out no longer are soaring and then really kind of like awe inspiring they're really kind of grounded in in loads of effects and in a very claustrophobic mix the claustrophobic mix that really has every song kind of feeling too alike for comfort and really kind of kills a few of the very tender moments on this LP I felt like one of my favorite tracks on here Newtown burnout could have been more stripped-down near the end you know sans all the effects and wacky noises it just would have been a good tune I really can't help but feel like the sound effects on that track aren't helping or enhancing the music in the same way they would be on fields or strawberry jam centipede Hertz's is definitely really chaotic and hectic but it's kind of to the point where it's impeding on the enjoy ability of some of these tracks like the track mercury man for example which i think is the kinds of the kind of the kinds of the kind of the kinds of the best melody on this entire album and a nice kind of emphasis on the upbeat toward the beginning of the track kind of reminds me of like a psychedelic weird glitchy reggae tune or something like that but the thing is especially toward the end of the track where things get really kind of melodic you really kind of get more sounds in there the vocals which are really kind of just bringing all the emotion to the tune are just shoved down underneath everything and in a really I guess unflattering way or the song rosio which has a really great melody as well you have a bass a guitar of beat on their vocals but the thing is the the tune is good there's nothing really all that weird or psychedelic about the sounds of those instruments are making everything surrounding the track is what's kind of what's making a weird sound and to me it just kind of feels like well what's the point you could easily subtract all of these effects and the same exact tune I'm not seeing these sounds or effects adding to the song it's just kind of like looking at yourself in a foggy mirror and just like trying to wipe it and wipe it and wipe it and it just does not come clear the track monkey riches for example is another track that to me feels too chaotic to the point where the verse and the chorus just don't really have that much contrast when you hear that shift in the song there's not really a different feeling or anything like that the other issue that I have with this hi everyone Anthony Fantino here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for you review murder construct results these guys are a metal outfit and a bit of an extreme music supergroup performing this incredibly tight technical and grimy brand of death metal infused with grindcore so you do get heavy dissonant guitars plenty of double bass drum death growls and on top of that the sporadic frenetic and and very intense and fast nature of grindcore kind of being executed within put together of course these guys are not the first to combine death metal and grindcore I mean the two genres really kind of came of age together and members of this band have played plenty of grind themselves in other bands like exhumed phobia foetus eaters also cattle decapitation a band that has put out one of the biggest grind albums of this year but the thing is these guys have also been in groups that kind of work outside of that grindcore circle as well they are coming together on this new full-length debut LP with a filthy dirty sound there's really nothing refined about the brutality on this album except for maybe the speed so I can assure you that on this thing overproduction is not a problem these guys are really fast but not too much about flash which can kind of be a pro or con on this album it does lead to some really just unrelenting pummeling brutality that just does not let up kind of redundant that sentence was but in this very unrelenting nature it can be difficult to kind of pull out unique qualities about every track despite the fact that they are there most of the tracks on this thing are around two minutes and that's great because nothing is worse than a grind song that just goes on for too long and over the course of these tracks murder construct works in a lot of nice progressions phases sections like the second track on here under the weight of wood which has some really nice hellish dark tremolo melodies and then chord progressions toward the beginning of the track and then around one minute 20 seconds this surprising bridge pops up out of nowhere and the bass line really kind of comes to the front of the song and place a nice counterpoint against the guitars and it's it's actually kind of surprising how much the bass does pop out in any given track on this album kind of rare for music this extreme I love the heavy and harmonized riffs and and guitar leads toward the end of the track compelled by mediocrity just really vile and the chord progression on the track dead hope actually kind of has like a slightly black metal quality to it even though this thing is pummeling especially with the drums which are incredibly detailed just so fast so perfect there is nice melody on this album as well but if the drums don't distract you from that the horrific vocals from extremely talented metal vocalists Travis Ryan will for a majority of this album his vocals are just swallowing the mix on this thing and it's really because he is kind of a man of a thousand demonic voices deep guttural ugly lows that get especially just on the track compelled by mediocrity when you kind of get a multitrack they're just different vocal takes just all kind of hitting your ears at once you do kind of have those straightforward death growls you do have shrill high-pitched wretches the guy is just all over the place and a lot of the times you'll hear these voices kind of trading spots off on the album you'll hear them singing together in unison which would be no surprise if you've heard this guy sing on any number of cattle decapitation albums the song structures on this LP which I already have mentioned a little do have a lot to offer in terms of variation as well like one of the longer tracks on here the three-minute track next life which comes right out just blazing just these drumbeats to me that that remind me of D beats blast beats heavy riffs and then right toward the middle the track just really kind of makes this quick transition to some really slower darker moody or arpeggios it's like the first part of the track really kind of beats you unconscious and then the second just throws you in a body bag and drags you away and the closing track on here too has a nice progression a nice change from beginning to end it starts off with just this really pummeling introduction which is a little run-of-the-mill but after that it slows down things get dark there's a musical passage the band is playing but all of a sudden you know it kind of fades and the same musical passage is being played but the instrumentation has changed into strings sitar piano hand percussion I thought the shift the transition was okay but once the instrumentation was there doing what it was doing it sounded good you know as far as negatives on this LP go there are some tracks that I do feel I kind of go by in a blur without really making a serious impact among a number of tracks that are so heavy and just hard fast and in-your-face another negative to me is that I kind of feel like yeah these guys got together in this supergroup to do this album but what did they really do here that they couldn't do in their respective bands or haven't already done to an extent if anything they've just kind of brought together all the best qualities of their respective bands and then just kind of put them on one record which isn't a bad thing now I know a lot of you guys who watch the channel on a regular basis are not into music like this necessarily I mean you know tread lightly be open-minded it's kind of like eating broccoli rabe you know music like this if you eat a vegetable like broccoli rabe you know what's gonna hit you first if you've never tried it before is the strong strong strong bitter taste but if you learn to cook with it taste it what you should or shouldn't pair it with food wise you not only taste past that bitterness once you know you get used to it but you also learn to kind of appreciate the bitterness in balance with everything else the food has to offer I'm feeling a light too decent ate on this album if you guys give it a listen what did you think about it did you love it did you drink that why and what should i review normal collections minimal collections minimal collections animal collections but remember the good comment the great rate and only the strong subscribe Anthony Fantana murder construct forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music nerd time for a full-length album review holy other help holy other held this guy is a UK music producer this is full-length debut album on triangle records you know the record label that houses new music from clams Casino Balam good Evie in Christ many more oh whoa whoa oh oh oh whoa whoa this label pretty much covers the deeper darker more atmospheric side of beat music very Spacey Basie and fog machine worthy electronic music all over this label if that even sounds remotely interesting to you and you have no clue a triangle records is I implore you go check them out and when it comes to all of those adjectives that I just used wholly other definitely follows suit and the with you EP that he dropped last year kind of set the tone for his musical style very ethereal and glossy synthesizers samples and drones kind of building a really really vast and in that soundscape he cuts a lot of very emotive and and well-executed vocal samples in a way it kind of reminds me of like burial but slow Jamz like a romantic version of burial holy other definitely has influences from the worlds of hip-hop and downtempo a lot like the other people on the triangle Records label but there's almost this like subtly implied R&B influence on on his music and it's not like you know necessarily poppy catchy upbeat commercial radio R&B it is like slow jam R&B but played at like half speed these extremely molasses slow wet silky you know musical experiences all these characteristics added up to a very good ep and now holy others kind of taking them to a full-length LP and there are some standout tracks like tens past and and past tension or the title track on here - all of which features some some nice beats and grooves slow like I said some nice vocal samples as well tense past and past tension that I just mentioned they are kind of sister tracks that share a lot in common though there are actually a lot of songs on this LP that share many things in common they're actually songs on this LP that share a lot in common with songs from holy others EP that he dropped last year specifically the track no where with the opener of this album where but with the W in parentheses I think from the titles that the similarities between these two tracks is is kind of being implied like I said I do like the fact that all the other executes his style pretty well I mean he has a style does it well and he incorporates some interesting influences on this LP like future garage you will kind of get some future garage rhythms kind of popping up here and there and I would say even though the atmosphere is Spacey and slow it is not very druggie you know it's it's just kind of cavernous maybe sexy maybe also kind of cold - I do get that feeling from tracks on here as well kind of cold maybe a little bleak my main issue with this LP though is that some tracks really do not hit as well as others and kind of go by without really kind of a unique or or interesting characteristic about them whether it be a good vocal sample or just a beat or a synth texture that is specific to that track there is a lot of redundancy on this album and that's why I don't think this album really has enough variety even across it's it's pretty short 35 minutes to really kind of be an album you know the mood and the atmosphere and the production is there but as a whole listening experience from beginning to end it gets really kind of mundane I guess there were a lot of tracks on here that just felt shallower than others and I just couldn't really dive into them because there wasn't a lot to listen to but you know there's still some good tracks to take away from this thing and overall I do like wholly others style and I found this thing to be you know decent at least likable feeling a light decent six on this thing what did you guys think of it if you've given it a listen love it hate it why and what should I review next remember the good comment the great rate but only the strong subscribe Anthony Fantana all the other held forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for your review for tetes pink thank you okay this is the latest release from longtime electronic music producer Kieran Hebden aka Forte who has spent a good chunk of this year sporadically releasing tracks on 12-inch singles off of his self started record label text records and this thing pink is pretty much a compilation of those released tracks now at this point his career for tte has kind of abandoned the really instrumentally russian and layered electro-acoustic instrumentals that make albums like rounds you know his album rounds so celebrated I don't mean to make that sound bitter because I actually you know like the direction that he's been heading and especially on his last full-length album there is lovin you which was one of my favorite electronic music albums of 2010 and there are references to his old self on this album especially on the last track she only likes to fight which is a really pretty track and has a post-rock esque instrumental escalation but for the most part these days four tet has been embracing the hypnotic repetitive sounds of house music but his angle when it comes to house music tech house micro house is to just create some really subtle sounds very pretty and nicely executed vocal samples as well examples from there's love and you love cry and and the opening track as well and that mix of house music structure and repetition together with his his usual experimentation his search for some some interesting sounds is here on pink I would actually say on this compilation Summa for tetes most textured beats ever are on this thing it starts right from the get-go on the track lock which has some really nice hand percussion and the beat there's just a lot of interesting sounds going on I mean that is just really what makes a lot of these tracks just really nice quality and and unique sounds what does kind of bug me about this track and a lot of tracks on this compilation though is that nothing is introduced or built upon or just sort of it added to a track all that subtly or with a delicate hand you have a lot of hard ins and outs it's not the worst thing in the world but it does kind of bring a robotic quality too for tetes production that I wasn't totally in love with I'm used to him really just kind of sequencing things or introducing things with I don't know a bit more Flair and I wouldn't say it's it's it's a complete lack of effort or anything like that because once certain sounds start in these tracks for Ted does work to kind of keep a nice progression going like the pops and clicks that fill the beat on the track Jupiters or the rolling just just strangely sequenced high hats on the track 128 harps and of course the UV harp sound on that track as well as is beautiful the last track out here pinnacles though is is easily my favorite has an amazing rush of just sounds and instrumentation that that just kind of hops in every so often when these jazzy piano chords kind of a rise in the track it's the only song here that to me really references that older side of for tet where you are hearing a lot of acoustic instrumentation and it sounds like it's it's kind of happening live it's easily the most detailed track on the album but a lot of other tracks on here kind of underwhelming because of their lack of detail I just don't find them to be as engaging good beats and grooves but you know hmm because the way some of these tracks move tends to be a little mundane for me sometimes and and maybe obvious as well because the execution of some of these tracks can't kind of deflate my excitement for them pretty fast like on a chorus or lion or pyramid the the tracks on here though are a feast I even really liked the 11 minute track piece for Earth which is kind of a very long vast ambient synthesizer piece which was was kind of breathtaking and it's in its simplicity III didn't really come away loving this compilation I just felt like some tracks were really not as stimulating as others this is definitely a must listen for for tet fans and even worth checking out for people who may just be curious about his stuff because while it wasn't mind-blowing it certainly was easy to get into and could be a nice starter for some people I'm feeling a decent too strong 7 on this thing what did you guys think of it if you've given oh listen did you love it hate it why remember the good comment the great rate but only the strong subscribe Anthony Fantana for Ted forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internets busiest music nerd albums this long take a lot out of me in this album is the seer the latest LP from the longtime experimental rock outfit swans I've covered this band before on the channel reviewed their last LP in 2010 which at the time was their first album in over ten years the band broke up in the 90s ended up performing in the in the 2000s and there is a bit more information in that review you can watch it it's linked in the description box of this video now truth be told swans returned to putting out studio records was not as exciting for me as it was for some other people and not because I'm not a fan I am I just felt like swans last effort was a bit of a letdown unfortunately kind of subdued a none adventurous for a record carrying the swans name there were a lot of very dark funky sounds on this record and despite the fact that the band has indulged in sounds like that before on previous records I couldn't help but feel like this album was more like a michael gira solo LP or a record from another one of his side projects Angels of Light which wasn't completely surprising considering that a lot of the members in this current phase of swans career were previously collaborating with jira on that project before he kind of jumped and did the swans thing I really just kind of came away from rope to the sky hoping that the band was just getting warmed up and I feel like the seer confirms that the band's definitely kind of getting the ball rolling again on dishing out the sounds that that I would normally associate with this band you know the noisy experimental inspiringly weird and challenging music that they're known for because they're really getting back to the longer tracks those drones just that that overall strangeness that was so awesome about the later period of swans career with loads of drones cacophonous instrumentation noise escapes and mind-numbing repetition and of course michael gira is very disturbing lyrics and and abrasive sounds of all shapes and sizes rumbling overpowering over modulated shrill love that word considering the kind of music the band puts out swans fans are really the type of people who beg to be tortured and abused and on this LP swans are happy to oblige the most impressive thing about this LP overall I would say easily is the fact that swans maintain such a high high level of tortured despair for a majority of this two-disc two hour-long very ambitious album which I will start describing right from the beginning I will try to keep my descriptions of tracks and musical moments succinct because I really do feel like I could talk for as long as this album lasts now the opening track on the first disc lunacy just has an amazingly hellish chorus on it it is just bone-chilling and the track actually features members of the band low hell of how these chorus vocals just trade spots with some really heavy abrasive instrumentation it is the perfect opener for this thing it kind of sets the stage for what you're gonna get throughout the album some strange vocals a little bit of organ in there I believe some guitar and some hammered dulcimer as well kind of chopping it up in the mix the next track mother of the world has these really sharp repetitive riffs on it guitar riffs that that play this very stuttering groove that is very unlike any groove I have heard in any sort of rock inspired song it's very attention grabbing and you can hear Michael Cera's vocal on the track just it's just heavy breathing into the microphone is just weird like I listen to this tracking and other tracks on this album and just think what are you doing it's freaking me out man at first I wasn't too impressed with this track thought it was a little too repetitive the groove itself is repetitive but the band works to subtly build atmosphere around this groove more instrumentation just more sounds kind of fly-in swans really do love repetition on this LP I like the subdued outro on this track too that it kind of breaks into after after a really intense build-up is very mournful very funky now the title track in the middle of this first disc is thirty minutes long and it is surprisingly cohesive considering its length however this is not the first long-form song that swans has written like this the only thing that really kind of feels disconnected from the rest of the track is the very noisy drone that introduces the whole thing and it kind of dies out before the real meat of the track begins and the track features this really slowly building groove before Michael Gira's vocals just kind of get multi-tracked on top of each other and in this very kind of chanting repetitive hypnotic way he's trying to sing I see it all I see it all I see it all and really strange and the track builds into a very high high noisy just ear-shattering climax and right after that it just kind of breaks into these syncopated hits of drums guitar just basically every instrument the swans can muster all crashing down over and over and over I should also mention that there are some slower moments on this track that also kind of remind me of God's beat but I digress back to this crashing instrumentation though this point can seem especially repetitive maybe the most repetitive point on the entire album work and it can really kind of drag on I'm sure for a first-time listener but every time you get a hit you get a crash of instrumentation swans work to kind of make the dissonance qualities of these hits different like subtly different either there are just different tones buried in the crashes or they are just slowly getting more and more intense or or altered as the track progresses and I really like the dusty soundscape that finishes the track off there's a nice harmonica in there it's it's a really interesting serene calm after the storm the track the seer returns features Jarboe on the track you know coming back into the fold with swans although I found her vocal contribution on the song to be maybe a little too subtle I would have loved to have heard her just more front-and-center this track features one of the more straightforward grooves on the entire LP and it could even be catchy and kind of easy to show people who don't know about swans if it were not for Michael Gira's very freakish vocal delivery faceless is a technical melodic and pretty progressive death metal band from California this is their third full-length album it's been about four years since the band released their last LP planetary duality and for a lot of fans it has been worth the wait merely because of the amount of progression that this band has shown on this new LP now LP is like planetary duality are just nothing but straight-up proficient brutality clean production with no room for four errors or muddiness some amazing drumming to back it all up and some really surprising colorful and just very interesting and creative segues breaks and riff changes which all kind of wind the tracks on this LP into some very unpredictable song structures this is definitely worth looking into if technical death metal is what you're after however in the case of this you know let's start with one of my biggest issues with this LP and it is just the overall lack of just direct impact that this LP has I just don't think the songs the playing on this album is as fast as abrasive as winding the overall energy is just not as savage I feel like the faceless take a lot of the exciting and interesting and progressive riffs that are usually in their music and trained them in trade them in for slower moody or more melodic guitar passages and a set of clean vocals that I can not stand but the vocals are my real issue on this album the melodies overall to me just just the the less brutality that this album has to offer would be fine if I felt like that the more melodic parts weren't being delivered so that you could have these really campy vocals on top of them it just starts right from the beginning with three tracks which are kind of like a suite for the album it is the Auto theose movement I'm impressed with how the band can write these multifaceted songs with a lot of detail the somber piano and the strings that just start this LP off just sound like they could fit very properly into a cinematic funeral procession but once those vocals kick in my potential for loving this thing is just drained because to me it sounds like a pretty run-of-the-mill radio metal vocal that you usually hear soaring over the hook and the way that sometimes they intertwine with the death growls it just really leaves a bad taste in my ears introducing clean vocals into extreme metal doesn't necessarily equate to a bad thing in in all cases I just feel like in the case of faceless it's a move toward not experimentation but but the middle-of-the-road now the second part of the auto theists movement is is a little bit more like it I like those tight drums and guitars just pushing out some really brutal vicious melody and riffing and I actually like the way the band starts incorporating keyboards and some symphonic sounds just seeping them in slowly on the track that to me is is fleshing the sound out in a tasteful way but once those clean vocals pop in again it just dies for me and it kind of feels like something off of the last opeth LP the third part of the Otto feeis movement sounds even more like the last Opeth LP especially with the lead singer crooning very dramatically that God is dead and things start sounding really tacky when this circus instrumentation starts popping in out of nowhere it just kind of feels like something a much more sporadic band like mr. bungle or or Fantomas would do with with a much more interesting angle at times operatic vocals will will sort of pop in on this moment of the album which just totally screamed Devin Townsend to me but on a less grandiose scale making it kind of less impressive after the third track the faceless sort of starts getting back to the band that I know they can the clean vocals I don't care for are still there but just not on the level that they were during that first third the type very well played and unforgiving guitars are back I'm loving those melodies despite the fact that this band is pretty extreme they have a nice sense of melody at their fingertips I'm loving the chord progression on the track accelerated evolution and the song after it to the syncopated explosion of drums and distorted guitar chords and then guitar leads on the closing track here is awesome as well the melody especially reminds me of something off of that last Agalloch LP I do think these guys have a nice ear for some interesting sounds as well like when you hear the very metallic percussion on the introduction of the track 10 billion years but still whenever these guys take me out of brutal high they just drop me down to the pits of just boredom and and lack of interest when they lay on those ultra melodic moments that don't really have a lot of pomp to them and incorporate those vocals that just are really kind of nasally at some points bland at some points they didn't want to put out the same record again you know but I'm just not sure if this was the way to flesh things out to grow things too I guess build upon the model I'm very very on the fence with this LP unfortunately I'm feeling a strong five on this but if you've listened to it and I know some of you out there have what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why and what should I review next anthony Fantana the faceless Auto theism forever you [Music]
