beams is this dude's fifth full-length album and the follow-up to what was pretty much his breakthrough LP black city on which he presented a pretty definitive sound the structures and just delivery of micro house and techno executed with the darkest and strangest textures and tones imaginable and he graced these visceral shadowy grooves with his very moody baritone vocal what was really kind of keeping me from loving that LP though is that I felt some of the beats didn't have enough variation enough progression to them and lyrics kind of tend to be a weak point for Matthew on on this LP as well however like I said he does have a style all his own which he does evolve on on theme he beams now overall this LP does have that same dark and tortured delivery that you expect from Matthew deer but I would say this is maybe easily his most upbeat project yet he hems back the reverb he heads back the obscurity he heads back just that feeling of desolation and he delivers a series of focused beats where the instrumentation is not only clear but kind of colourful maybe even bordering on bubbling though I would say they are more like Tarr bubbles but when the Tarbell's pop they smell like pink bubble gum especially on the track ahead of myself which to me instrumentally is is a very surprising change from the sometimes very bleak black city and what's awesome is that this change has not ruined the feel or the emotions of Matthew dears music I actually think it's made him a more interesting character because on beans the clash between the fun danceable beats and the very weird strange sounding man singing over them is that much greater like on the track do the right thing it's a softer track on this LP has a very pleasing beat a nice soft cowbell in there strategically placed some glassy synthesizers and Matthew dears very bellowing croon keeping things kind of creepy because as he's singing and that is creepy in and of itself he's thrown out these lyrics about digging a grave or about how his heart weighs a ton in snakes or how his flesh is burning like a ton of flames falling from the Sun I actually think this track is the sweetest piece of synth pop I've ever heard from this guy and yet it is disturbingly morbid it's a pretty surreal song especially when you look at the lyrics actually for me a lot of the slower tracks on here do get pretty surreal even the last track on here temptations it's a track that to me is just equal parts seductive and unsettling but the songs on here that are even best at that first one seductive are the ones that have the harder beats like the opening track on here her fantasy which features all these strange synth loops I mean a sea of different textures from glassy and just smooth to soaring and then vibrant or just kind of like darken and rough and the groove underneath these since just totally remind me of David Byrne Talking Heads I would actually say those two things are the most prevalent influence on this entire LP I've never heard Talking Heads come through so strong on this dude's music and as long as we're making comparisons there are moments on this LP that totally remind me of like Nine Inch Nails and there's something in the back of my head that just totally says hey man when he croons sounds a bit like Marilyn Manson if that pisses you I don't give a look and despite this newfound level of color Matthew dears personality is is just as odd and freakish as ever even on a track like head Cage which came from Matthew dears previous EP which I didn't really like but I did like that track head Cage is really the Poppaea song on here and has a hook about going out tonight and even though that vocal is a little corny it is corny though the lyrics are a bit corny he does kind of give this very eerie quality to just kind of leaving the house and just kind of sneaking out to have a good time now if I do have some gripes with this LP the second-to-last track on here is definitely a little underwhelming but maybe more of a grower the tracks up and out and over time do to me kind of rely on repetition a little bit too much there's enough progression for me plus those two tracks for whatever reason they're right next to each other kind of fizzle out at the end as opposed to ending abruptly or kind of pulling together a proper finish but I'm really enjoying all the other tracks on here a lot and what I guess I'm most impressed by on on this LP is that like black City this album does have a sense of place and I like that Matthew Deere was able to keep things dark keep things weird but bring a different place to the listener it's an album that to me lives in this weird dimension that that for some reason is both gloomy gloomy and like inviting like you want to be there you know I've tried really hard to talk about and describe the overall experience of this album and yet I still kind of feel like I have fallen short but that's just really kind of overall how I feel about this thing feeling a strong eight and remember though this album is coming from a weird place it is not going to feel totally alien to you I mean you know you have poppy hooks on here you have since you have Beats you have loops samples vocals lyrics all things that are familiar to you and yet they kind of create this otherworldly sensation and and that's really what I'm loving about it um for watching love you 80k dance forever

hmm hi everyone Anthony Fantan out here internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review devotion from Jessie where oh she's there right there and the Wow really she's over here even on your wall it's not funny Jessie where is an up-and-coming pop singer from the UK this her debut full-length LP my first exposure to her was singing on that subtract album last year that I loved that I thought was so great she had a vocal appearance on just one single track then I started hearing singles and and promotional tracks from the cell P kind of building up to the release of the album I ran into 110 percent which has this future garage style vocal sampling this twittering busy rhythm some smooth vocals and synthesizers it has a really bouncy rich bassline - I didn't really feel like it was a gripping tune with how it was delivered it was kind of quiet throughout not really many climaxes you know I'm totally for the breaking just the snapping of traditional song structures or just adding on them and experimenting with them but this to me just feels like no structure but another single from this LP I love wildest moments the B is so epic the presentation of the song period is is pretty grandiose and I like the lyrics on the song too about this couple putting all this effort in sort of making this relationship work but these two people in the relationship have a full understanding of what the potential for this relationship could be that is what keeps them going the verse and the chorus have two very distinct feels to them really dynamic song the chorus segues into a beautiful refrain we can be the greatest we can be the great and I love how you get that dark choral effect when Jessie Ware's sings or we can be the worst of all just kind of adding that that Moody to that section of the lyrics because while these people in this relationship keep going because they know that potential of how great this thing could be they also know that it can be pretty terrible as well another track that was put out before this LP sweet talk is another great pop tune but it has a bit of vintage feel to a kind of a retro futuristic going back to the 80s with the drumbeat and with the synthesizers and with the guitar leads that kind of interject between lyrics I like the way the instrumentation changes on the second verse maybe the hook could be a little bit bigger maybe the vocals bite a bit from little dragon but sweet talk and wildest moments are like everything I look for in a pop song this album is titled devotion and if it is devoted to anything it is the warm and smooth soul vibes of artists like Janet Jackson Whitney Houston Billy ocean Patrice Rushen all those names rhymed I think Jesse where definitely takes influence from those artists but has a much kind of killer vibe to her music even though I thought the singles to this LP were a little a little hit or miss I was still pretty excited for this thing thought it would bring some big things I would get a very classy kind of pop record however I feel like once I delved into this thing from beginning to end all these small issues that I had on a couple of the singles just really got amplified throughout this thing there are a lot of very underwhelming moments lack of climaxes and and when Jesse where does manage to adventure a little bit it can be a kind of bad experiment like the first track on here the title track it's just not a good opener you've got these twinkling synthesizers and and Jesse is is vocalizing with some kind of forgettable lyrics over this groove it starts off okay but there's not really any kind of change or significant progression and the bass line on this thing is terrible as far as I can tell the track is in the key of D and and thing is pretty much in a major scale except for the baseline which is playing D and then kind of sliding down to a second note which if it were going to be in the D major scale it would be a diminished sixth but nothing else in the instrumentation seems to be hinting toward playing or referencing that diminished six so it's kind of dissonant for no real reason there are more tracks on here that have grooves that are better than the opener but they two also kind of lack anything interesting in terms of progression and what hurts them even more is that the lyrics here and there can be pretty amateur or monotonous I feel like you definitely could make the case that this is a sophisticated pop record this pop record has a very expensive dress on it sips wine delicately it's not bubblegum by any means whatsoever but despite the sophistication I actually think most of this album is underdeveloped and pretty weakly improvised thankfully toward the middle of the LP another solid pop track with a structure comes out to play nightlight though the hook is pretty big I like the strings on the song - nice production the lyrics can be so cheesy that it's a song I kind of hate to love though much of this album is very chill very fragile and relaxed the ending tracks seem to get even quieter and and sadly to me it only adds up to even more underwhelming moments overall for me devotion is is really really spotty it puts forth an image and an attitude that would make you think that the album is more progressive than it really is I am totally down for embracing the past but Jessie ware doesn't really do anything new with it or adventurous with it and I don't think she's put forth the effort to avoid the pitfalls that kind of come with this style of music - the majority of these tracks are heavily pulling from the kinds of R&B records that right now are gathering dust in bins in thrift stores across America I can see why this album would appeal to other people more than me but I didn't like I mean I'm pretty much sticking to the singles on this thing and and that's where my enjoyment of this album really kind of stops in a big way I'm feeling a decent too strong for on this thing but what did you guys think of it did you love it did you hate it why and what should I review next remember the good comment the great rape but only the strong subscribe Jessie we're devotion forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review eeprom metahuman this guy is a Portland music producer from what I understand this is his debut full-length LP album right now with with styles of electronic music like dubstep future garage footwork glitch hop wonky electronic music is really at the forefront of a lot of new and creative sounds right now and even though EPROM is not one of the bigger names in electronic music right now I think he's digging for new and interesting ideas with the best of them me his new album metahuman and this is such a headphone album not a phrase I use much to describe albums only when it's necessary usually I like to listen to stuff on the hi-fi on the speakers but not the case with this thing though this album's tracks do have a pretty bold and colorful attitude that you will find with most beat music producers of the glitch hop variety he Proms aesthetic is very quiet it's very subtle it's like a very calming party happening between your ears and what I love about this dude is is how he treats sound on some of these songs he just shoots for a lot of synthetic textures on this thing it sounds like he is treating and manipulating many of these sounds very very minimally not a lot of distortion not a ton of reverb he really likes to maintain that juicy lush very electronic vibe there sounds on here that are of an 8-bit quality there are a lot of rhythm sounds to me that sound akin to a lot of those snare and kick hits that you would usually hear coming out of an 808 but EPROM finds ways to kind of sequence these sounds really interestingly the opening tractor's has these plinking little tap and clicks that are kind of rolling they're kind of stuttering they're just skittering some of them are closed and very claustrophobic on the ear some of them are pretty distant in a very panoramic kind of way it's like a it's like turning a rain stick over the introduction on this track is like gently flicking microscopic water droplets at my ears then all of a sudden this bass II beat comes in it's really spacious there are a few bouncy echoes here and there maybe like a higher low-pass filter on something to kind of give it a low Phi aesthetic and the groove on the track is is interesting because it feels so kind of robotic and sterile usually something that would turn me off but I feel like it helps the track in this case because it brings a really unique flavor to the song this track really becomes a half human half robot incarnate there's something very strange about this track there's something very serious about it very Stern about it but you also have to keep in mind that there are bangers that come after this track there are bouncier and just harder hitting songs to a degree that come after this track this guy is definitely not making electronic music to bore you he wants it to sound like a good time but kind of a quiet good time like the track prototype and even though this track does have one of the heavier beats on the album EPROM is not about instant gratification the track opens up with an eerie synth drum with just so many layers just a casserole of synthesizer and it's so thick it's so beautiful then these arpeggiated riffs kind of come in and then just starts mmm denne denne denne denne denne denne denne antennae it's a great groove it's just a really kind of dark vibe and I like how he continues to kind of walk this weird tightrope or just kind of meet at this strange crossroads where the track is kind of loud but also very soft very kind of bare and skeletal the track can control after that feels even more skeletal it's like a dancehall track that would go over well in purgatory however around the sixth track for this thing this album kind of just jumped ship from the weird odd and somewhat unique world it had been building with the first portion of this album EEPROM starts bringing in these 8-bit synthesizers which make things a little bit brighter and I feel like I would like the sixth track that this starts on a bit more if the beat wasn't so plainly sequenced I get that this guy wants to bring some musical variety some stylistic variety to this album but I don't think every change adds up to a phenomenal track the track transparency has some subtle dubstep influences and the synthesizers and in the vocal samples but it's not really that memorable of a moment on the LP for me neither is the song variations which is kind of what the title says it is a variation on a phrase on an idea kind of bring it through different phases this parts hitting hard with a beat this part is the same musical phrase but it kind of sounds like it's being performed with the Spanish guitar that track kind of wears it to welcome for me really fast and the song right after that love number is just unashamed Flying Lotus worship and not even really like the best Flying Lotus worship I've ever heard the last portion of the album starts getting a little bit noisier a bit glitchy err and I like that this album starts strong it ends relatively strong but there is that kind of dry spot in the middle for me this dude has some serious chops too the way he puts tracks together even if at times the sounds themselves can seem pretty bare pretty rudimentary and just simple on the surface he can really create some unique atmospheres especially on the first portion of this LP but once he started to try on other things that's when this helped he really started to lose momentum for me but if you're looking for an electronic music album that just brings together like I said very quietly elements of dubstep music of glitch hop just some weird instrumentals for you beat heads then this is definitely something worth checking out yeah yeah I think beats you do yes you make beats yeah you make beats yes sir you make beats ah then show me those beats re a decent set forever

yes they always make them go BOOM BOOM BOOM BOOM [Music] I'm feeling that swag wrong JJ doom is the collaborative effort of MC MF doom aka doom all capitals and Janeiro jor-el this is their first full-length LP together and let me put this into context for you doom is easily the most infamous underground MC n producer of the very late 90s and early to mid 2000s on song after song after song he just uses this very low monotonous flow to spit these very abstract oddball rhymes with references so strange and esoteric that they'll make your head spin and on numerous albums of his he's always throwing out very weird cartoony sometimes apocalyptic and tortured song concepts but no matter how out there doom make it with a song there's usually some kind of underlying sense of humor there you usually some kind of goof just around the corner like steady losing momentum Oh eat a rapper one a day like syndrome all these things make doom likable the comedy just the the gritty flow his song topics his very shady lyrics and and the kind of gimmick he's got going with his mask which maintains the anonymity of his character or people for the most part know who he is and what he was affiliated with before he started the whole MF DOOM get up but he continues to perform as this character because he likes the image now MF DOOM in my opinion has had his share of great solo LPS operation doomsday food borne like this but some of his most popular albums have been collaborations with with other artists for example the danger doom LP he did with Danger Mouse and of course is his most celebrated release of all time I'm sure you already know it mad villainy which is the album he did with of course him on lyrics and Madlib handling the production side of things daddy loves these days doom has not really been working up to the prolific very prolific level that he was putting albums out at during his 2003-2004 period and in the meantime he hasn't been doing a lot of new production I mean that new maps to a cell P is pretty much old MF DOOM beats for the most part and he hasn't been doing a lot of features on other people's tracks to kind of keep his image his character his style in the ever-evolving consciousness of what's now the modern underground hip-hop playing field still his subtle influence remains on a lot of the artists that people are listening to right now the up-and-comers people from Odd Future bike this dude's flow in his style all the time even on some of their earliest mixtapes they're taking MF DOOM beats Joey badass uses MF DOOM own mark on this project as well and kind of sidestep the constant Madlib comparisons that this album is is definitely going to get and JJ did put doom on some interesting sounds that you wouldn't hi everyone Anthony Fantino here intranets busiest music nerd here to do a question comment thing over the past few weeks a lot of you may have been paying attention to the developing story involving the female the Russian female punk trio known as Pussy Riot they've been on trial in Russia for hooliganism and basically what they did is they went to the Russian Orthodox Church to kind of do an impromptu performance of a song that they had written and now they've basically gone through the whole trial process and had been found guilty and are now going to be sitting in prison for two years a lot of people from the first world have expressed just how much of an overkill this sentence has been but the band was able to offer some pretty awesome closing statements in regards to why they did this the trial their philosophy as well and really exposed this is not just being some kind of childish juvenile prank which some people have kind of labeled it as being I will throw some links below where you yourself can read the closing statements offered by the band and a lot of the motivation behind choosing the Russian Orthodox Church as just sort of a place to stage this protest is that it's kind of become a tool for politicians in that country to gain favor with the populace sounds familiar but out of all the things that the band has said about their philosophy and just their reasons for doing this in the trial I thought that this quote right here is the most interesting out of all of them in this closing statement I would like to describe my first-hand experience of running afoul of this system our school which is where the personality begins to form in a social context a person's personality forms in a social context in school any particularity of the individual are ignored there is no individual approach no study of culture of philosophy of basic knowledge about civic society officially these subjects do exist but they are still taught according to the Soviet model and as a result we see the marginalization of contemporary art in the public consciousness a lack of motivation for philosophical thought and gender stereotyping the concept of the human being as a citizen its swept away into a distant corner today's educational institutions teach people from childhood to live as automatons not to pose the crucial questions consistent with their age roughly into place of fear which was supposed to be inhabited by about 12 gods who lord it over various causes of human suffering death sickness starvation and more and to make things even more morbid this band's new LP their first album for the southern Lorde label has the title hasta la muerte which is to the death in Spanish these guys are aggressive as hell they're brutal as hell and they just deliver this building crumbling heaviness on track after track their earlier material did have a really aggressive energy but I think they really went above and beyond on this new LP really kind of bringing that hardcore punk ferocity with a sludge metal heaviness with the brand of low end that is very deserving of a spot in the southern Lord discography now southern lord has been carrying a lot of sludgy hardcore punk hybrids I have reviewed a handful of them a few of my most recent favorites have been black breath as well as the band males and Taylor young from nails Ashley does production on this LP and Greg Anderson of Sun comes in and contributes droney heavy loud guitars on a couple tracks too and the special attention that these guys have gotten this LP is really paid off because this album is so loud you cannot turn it down there are only two speeds at which you can go deaf to this LP fast and sort of fast so yes these guys are incredibly brutal and this extra attention that I just mentioned has brought a bit of detail character and finesse to the very blood-thirsty sound you do get this very heavy low-end sludge and doom Rivage mixed with that Punk speed but these guys also have the tendency to embark on these massive metalcore and beat down hardcore style breakdowns as well which I kind of have a love/hate relationship with I'm from Connecticut where we had a you have the drones you have the long strung out dumi riffs and some noise as well on here that kind of keeps things very dark and very tortured but those very fast and hard and and aggressive riffs reverb on them and Greg Anderson isn't even on this track it's nice to know that this band can kind of create those sounds pretty well on their own really kind of create a massive atmosphere but right they're not humble when it comes to the rumble especially when they lay on those breakdown riffs and back them up with some harmonious guitar leads it's kind of a rough quality to them that reminds me a lot of that freaking dyzma album that I liked so much last year after that the track laid to rest has a really nice mosh worthy groove and so does the song burn I mean just really great riffs progresses and I'm just like man how much louder can they make it oh wow it's louder now how much louder can they make it oh man it's louder now how much louder can they make it the title track has a off-putting as a female vocalist on it whose voice is manipulated with effects in a way that I didn't really care for though it was a nice addition to the album kind of broke things up brought some variation and the lyrics which are in English are very much about heartbreak and just suffering and in pain in relation to love or the lack of it coming from someone you want it from and the last two listened to any dubstep in the style of these guys are being inspired by right here like Skrillex or Nero or Rusco it's very clear that Muse is on the outside looking in on this whole dubstep thing it's like they didn't even make the effort to authentically recreate this sound and manipulate it to the point where it kind of became their own reinterpretation of it it really almost kind of sounds hi everyone Anthony Fantana here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a compilation review our Stevie Moore lo-fi high-fives and wink that to its door to get our CD more but they didn't have any there then so why you didn't care and I left thank you thank you this guy is easily one of the most interesting figures in DIY self recorded music DIY recording artists have had a long history of making music that is not technically up to snuff when it comes to the sound quality of more professional recordings but many who have decided to go it alone have made up for it with personality and sometimes even the development of their own sound because of the lack of constraints that comes with handling your own production artists like mount Erie or Daniel Johnston or smog or another artist so I'm sure a lot of you are familiar with who looks up to our Stevie Moore Arial pink now more has been self recording since about the 60s and he has taken full advantage of that lack of constraints that I mentioned recording not just pop and rock music but Noise music and punk music and avant-garde music as well electronics solo synth pieces spoken word and there are at least 200 different projects uploaded to the man's Bandcamp page right now old and new however despite the very alienating moments in his discography the parts in his discography that I'm sure you're just not going to like the songs that are good are so good and and so weird and and just so ear pleasing to me anyway that it makes plunging your hands into his discography and just digging through it kind of worth it Stevie's whole career has just kind of been defined by exploration for the sake of it good or bad and to become an art Stevie Moore fan you kind of have to have that same characteristic about you're listening that he does about his creating and I think this new compilation could be kind of a gateway drug to that because it really is a collection of 14 tracks that are some of Stevie's more accessible moments for sure it pretty much just stays within the pop and rock realm with a few weird exceptions the opener on this compilation pop music is not one of my favorite songs of his I think it's a better statement than it is a song however it kind of is a perfect opener for this compilation because it really kind of sets the bar for the weirdness the melody on this thing is just so jagged it's just so angular it's performed in this very strange falsetto vocal the first two tracks on this thing really are kind of choppy water for me after that things seem to smooth out with the track why should I love you which comes from one of my favorite are Stevie more albums glad music it is one of the funnier love songs that I've ever heard period and you can really tell on this song that Stevie is recording really in another place in another time and I just prefer this sound of his older recordings so much more than the sum of his newer ones which have a more kind of digital quality to them still that doesn't stop a next song from being very awesome Dutch me which is a very syrupy very I guess melancholic kind of slow jam featuring aerial pink on vocals I'm pretty sure it's actually cut from the collaborative album the two of them put out recently some acoustic numbers come in after that although I'm not a huge fan of the track big mistake it meanders a little bit for me but afterwards here comes the summer it's a song that I've already known from our Stevie more but it seems a little revamped on this thing some extra reverb to kind of enhance that large phil spector esque the an Aram excel that really brings out the pet sounds qualities of this track that I know stevia was going for in at least the writing of the song anyway the track hurry up has these loud pounding drums where the gate sort of seems to be messed with a little bit with some muddy guitar Stevie Moore is whispering literally about hurrying up on the track it's one of the stranger subject matters on the song that and the the last track which is hilarious we're Stevie Morris singing lyrics over and over and over saying things like I'm tired of singing about girls because I can't find any the man has a lot of musical eccentricities but he clearly has a lot of wit and just comedy to to his lyrics at times too however I will say that this compilation is kind of hit or miss and I feel like that comes with the territory of writing so much music and striving to make every song kind of different or unique in its own way you're gonna be trying things that aren't necessarily great ideas just to make the song different which kind of makes an album or a compilation not the best kind of format to experience our Stevie more in my opinion I mean sure it's a great way to get interested and be introduced to the man but my most rewarding experiences with our Stevie Moore's music have always been when I've just blindly kind of headed into whatever project or album he's put up on the internet and just cherry-picking what I think is a great moment you know had of whatever he's put out there and just kind of letting it be that so I did like this compilation not too much though it felt kind of like a strong six to a light seven for me so what did you guys think of this compilation if you've heard it did you love it hate it why and what should I review next anthony Fantana or Stevie Moore forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music nerd doing a sort of somewhat kind of monthly segment called y-you know review where i talk about group of albums that have come out within the past couple months that i have overlooked haven't gotten a chance to review and i figured i could just kind of give a quick opinion on them gauntlet style starting things off guided by voices latest LP class clown spots a UFO the second full-length album the legendary experimental lo-fi indie rock band has put out this year of course their latest releases not sounding all too low phi especially this one being much less psychedelic and obtuse abstract than the last full-length album they put out which i gave a kind of on the fence review to i would actually say that this is the album that the band should have put out first it really would have been a much more accessible listen for people kind of grouping around them because there was a hiatus before they started releasing albums again this year this is is much more easy on the ears definitely something worth checking out i think it is on par with the other accessible albums that these guys have to offer like half smiles decomposed but still nothing extremely thrilling exciting or just revolutionary for guided by voices okay next one an album that a lot of people were asking me to talk about the new Gojira album hope I'm pronouncing that correctly these guys are pretty famed for their very clean progressive and inspiring approach to death metal especially off very celebrated albums like from Mars to Sirius which is a very long winding riff Odyssey and I guess I was kind of sad to see that fewer of those so brach elements have made it onto this new album and they're not really being replaced with anything I feel like on this LP the band has simplified their sound to the point where it really kind of sounds like radio metal just the the chugga-chugga riffs and and the hooks especially on the title track strike me as something that I feel could be played right after a disturbed song and and few radio listeners would you know click to another station which is fine if you're into that kind of thing but I am NOT particularly though this album does take you pretty clean and just well-produced approach to death metal that I know is very popular right now this is just not as impressive or ambitious as gojira's previous releases next the self-titled Evo band album out now on Sub Pop Records these guys are an Ethiopian pop band with some really foreign grooves and bright horns there are some pretty catchy tracks on here just a lot of personality a lot of spice musical spice but there are some tracks that do under well me because I don't feel like as a unit these guys play together that intensely and I wish some of the solos were a bit flashy ER on here too but outside of that it's it's worth checking out if you're looking for something with more of an international aesthetic next the new antlers EP under C these guys are very soft dreamy indie rock band with some pretty celebrated releases hospice Burst Apart neither of which I am really a fan of and if you are into them that's fine these guys if you're unfamiliar with them are known for their very subtle delivery that's supposed to be big on emotions and and concepts but still even on this EP the antlers continue to create the most simulated sadness in underground rock and pop today the onslaught continues with four new tracks on this EP all of which kind of experiment with some more atmospheric ambient and more ethereal sounds and that may be exciting for fans to kind of hear the band breach new sonic territory but none of the noises none of the textures were really gripping me I just found this EP to be kind of underwhelming I just don't really connect with this band emotionally and that's it next the new Jeff the Brotherhood album hypnotic nights these guys are a power pop duo this is their latest LP loaded with songs that are built on rough distortion simple hooks served a la Weezer with a bit of a STONER attitude I feel like Jeff the Brotherhood continued to have just uniquely bad lyrics on their songs but they also sort of seemed to be conscious of how bad they are and can have a level of just a tongue-in-cheek Ness to it and that's fun I do think this band is fun pretty much every LP they have put out on some level is fun to listen to at least once and they certainly have energy too but I just feel like their songs can be kind of hit or miss or just to alight their influences to records of 2010 this band's self-titled LP and major chases that album with a style that sounds more like just traditional rock songwriting the band has toned down the guitar heroism a little bit all memorable I feel like Fang Island has tried to make I guess a more mature album this time around and they opened it up with a really great introductory track which seems like a more refined version of is a bit monotonous but he is just so quiet on this thing he's almost at a mumble with some of these tracks which I could totally see him getting away with if I was more into his lyrical content which nuances in meaning to what Jeremiah J is rapping about but what I have picked up of it I didn't really find to be all that poignant if I'm going to go down this sort of quiet weird alternative hip-hop understated flow but but just has a bit of a raspy weird quality to it that I like and the beats that he puts together are pretty strange I did find it to maybe be a little too obtuse I would have but even if that LP is a smidge like this EP it's going to be pretty interesting and man this thing is just such a mishmash of sounds and styles art pops synth pop just electronic music and hip hop as well with guests rapping on here from RZA of wu-tang clan and I guess my main issue with the EP which which is why I'm excited for the LP is that I don't feel like this level of experimentation is get a better grasp of the a vision that John has going for for this kind of collision of styles and finally the new Gaslight Anthem LP handwritten these guys are a New Jersey rock group latest album and they to me have toned down their punk rock spirit a lot on this album to kind of embrace their usual Bruce Springsteen influence even more hero worship can be pretty cool but I kind of feel like where the songwriting and the vocals do strike me as being very passionate I just didn't find this thing to be all that exciting of of a listen The Gaslight Anthem definitely have sanitized things a little bit have toned down just their rock energy to follow in these Springsteen footsteps I felt like they had something more original going on on their previous LPS and that is pretty much it for or hadn't just turned it off and walked away remember the good comment and the great rate but only the strong subscribe see you soon Anthony Fantana while you know review forever [Music]

I already know that tack tack tack tack haha hi everyone Anthony Fantino here internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review Domo Genesis no idols Domo Domo Genesis is an MC member of the California rap clique Odd Future he's released three major projects since he's been with them in 2010 it was rolling papers last year he had the utter the influence mixtape and this is his latest and really his biggest and most ambitious projects so far and what makes this project special is that not only are there some pretty notable underground hip-hop features on this thing but all the production is handled by The Alchemist someone outside the Odd Future circle somebody who is a pretty awesome and forward-thinking hip hop producer he's done remixes worked with artists like Jake one gangrene evidence Freddie Gibbs Action Bronson and he brings those connections to this album which leads to some features with a few of those artists like Freddie Gibbs and Action Bronson and somehow even space goes purp ends up on this thing as well as some Odd Future members and Odd Future affiliates like Vince staples now most importantly the alchemists involvement on this project leads to some really good beats right from the word go with the first instrumental on this thing prophecy you get these really dramatic pianos dramatic guitar solo cuts cuts looped around for a really nice effect a heavy kick drum and domo is flowing over the track a little bit nicer than he has on beats from his previous projects on the song fuck everybody else you get a very light string drone hanging in the background the beat is really sparse I like how you kind of have a a rolling snare drum kind of building up to the kick build bill building up to the kick on that there's a nice synth riff in there too it's really moody instrumental that I think is stellar and you get some high-pitched vocal samples that are chopped and looped on this thing too like on the instrumental for all and I love how on that track specifically the bass and the drum samples on that thing have such a warm analog feel to them like they were lifted straight from vinyl or straight from a cassette tape or something and the fluttering stints on the track me and my bitch are kind of pretty and very conducive for the love song style that that track is going for overall with no idols the production has a lot of versatility and I do have to give it to the alchemist because I don't feel like you really held back with any of the instrumentals on this thing whether he was giving Domo some instrumentals that he had made beforehand knowing that they were good or made them specifically for this project but I don't feel like this tape is perfect any and all issues I have with it pretty much lie with Domo a lot like that untitled Hodgy Beats EP that dropped earlier this year you get a slew of really great and creative colorful instrumentals given to an MC who is just really kind of bland because as far as the lyrics go on this thing all I am hearing are cliches boring stories and really corny similes like on the track me in my bitch which is a love song where domo pretty much wraps about his love for marijuana but makes marijuana into this woman like figure in the song really I can probably spend one hour on datpiff and find 50 songs that do the exact same thing and I have no reason to believe domos doing it any better than any one of them even the hook on me and my bitches is pretty trashy most of the tracks on here do not have hooks though it's pretty much Domo just rapping straight for one to two minutes depending on whether or not there is a verse from a guest and that would be fine if he was a great lyricist or had a flow that was constantly changing up wasn't so monotonous or just had a lot of wordplay to his verses but he doesn't like lifting up like the collar of Kanye and college dropout to be honest when I drop it I'm knocking the whole block out it's not terrible but he's not we saying anything just a lot of really empty brags left and right and nothing clever nothing funny document my awesomeness because I don't like to freestyle I like to hit the dougie while she's sucking on my penile there is not an original lyrical idea or song concept on this entire album and again that would be fine if Domo was proficient in what he's doing lyrically this album is very average it's very middle-of-the-road sure Domo does not come off as angry or hostile or angsty as some of the other odd future members most notably Tyler who is also on this LP but in comparison with with a guy like Tyler Domo just doesn't have that much personality he doesn't have a lot of force to his voice his flow doesn't really have any dynamic to it and he doesn't really have a story either what little story he does have which really kind of comes out on the first track sounds like the same story every other struggling internet rapper has despit about on their personal tracks I don't even feel like some of the guest features on here bring that much fire like Action Bronson I'm like the boss from the end of the Nintendo game my brain is on another level I can feel the devil's pain I've heard him spit at better lines than that but still I think action does kind of wrap Domo under the table on this album so does Freddie Gibbs and so does domos Odd Future cohorts Tyler brings more fire more excitement and Earl has more subtle wordplay worked in his verses so overall did I find anything horrible on this album no you know not really but was there anything that I was really interested in we're liking aside from the production know so I'm kind of feeling a strong four to a like five on this mixtape what did you guys think of it if you listened to it did you love it did you hate it why and what should I review next remember the good comment and the great rate but only is strong subscribed Anthony Fantana no idols The Alchemist forever [Music] [Music]

hi everyone Anthony Fantino here the Internet's sweatiest music nerd and it's time for a review own ad songs ohm is a duo that has been exploring the darker and the slower side of rock and metal music for about five studio albums now including this one and the duo originally formed after the seminal stoner and doom metal band sleep had disbanded the bassist and the drummer got together made ohm while Matt Pike guitar player and singer kind of went off and did high on fire I will admit I am much more of a high on fire guy and I'm not saying that you have to like either ohm or high on fire but when it comes to rock music that takes a more meditative approach ohm is easily one of my least favorite groups period but the thing is almost every album that own puts out displeases me for pretty much the same exact reasons for one Alf Cisneros vocals whose name I'm probably butchering to death but his vocals to me are just really underwhelming amateur just uninteresting and the bass lines that he plays to are pretty forgettable but I keep giving own a try whenever they put out a new LP because I love this style of music and their fans are really passionate about what they do plus they have continuously worked with Steve Albini to produce their records another guy I have an immense respect for and I don't think he would continue working with ohm if he didn't really love what they were doing now in the link 2000s the band had kind of a lineup change and I got excited to see where they would take their next album the duo now featured an owl on bass and vocals and ml a Moe's drummer for the band Grails and the first LP they made together I didn't love it but I could definitely see an improvement therefore sure the drums were a lot more detailed and Emmel as well as the guest musicians on this LP helped bring out those world music influences that always seem to be ever so subtly kind of influencing ohm's vibe on god is good you had a lot of flutes cellos Tambora drones the band was really expanding their sonic palette and it made me appreciate the hypnotic approach that they took the music so much more the vocals still were not really doing much for me the bass lines to me were still pretty mad but the extra instrumentation was well placed the production was good and listening to own jam for 10 or more minutes was sounding pretty good at this point and with this new LP ohm basically looks to continue expanding those international flavours in their music you have these Arabic melodies coming through on hello you have chance and just droning and repetitive bass lines contributing again to that hypnotic feel that always shoots for and another man whose name I'm about to butcher Robert ie key Aubrey Lowe who was on owns last LP just doing extra instrumentation is now on this album as a full-time member and he again is bringing that additional percussion the keys those Tambora drones has definitely progressed past their last LP I admire that they don't want to keep putting out the same album over and over and over but there are still things that seem to kind of be in the band's foundation that continue to bug me on this album owls vocals I really don't see the point in singing this way it just seems so campy it just seems so fake and just unappealing it really takes me out of the vibe of the music the bass lines to me are still pretty unimaginative but for the most part the bass the tone of the bass is great except on the second track where you do get some distortion on the bass and for some reason whatever distortion pedal they're using the low end of the bass gets totally cut out it's really muddy a distortion that doesn't sound good at all but aside from just the the lack of adventurous instrumentation though the instrumentation does sound good and is well produced the final nail in the coffin for this album for me is that the vibe of all of it is very very weak they certainly try you know the opening track on here is decked out with a guest female vocalist singing these chants in a different language you've got that extra hand percussion too but the entire song just feels like it is trying to get by on the Kitsch of sounding like it's coming from another country not really being all that interesting musically itself when Gorm's isn't giving me vocals I don't like or bass lines that I'm never going to remember they're just kind of creating this character of this music from another culture in this really long form Jam style delivery that I would like a lot more if if those things were kind of remedied so I'm really on the fence with this LP and continue to be with with all of ohms catalog I didn't really hear anything that is horrible on this album but I can't really find anything to celebrate either I'm really feeling like a strong five to a light six on this album what did you guys think of it did you love it did you hate it why and what should I review next remember the good common and the great rate but only the strong subscribe Anthony Fantana own forever

hello hello hello everyone Anthony Fantan oh here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for he review passion pit gossamer this is the sophomore LP from this Massachusetts indie pop sensation that hit it relatively big in 2008-2009 with a handful of very popular singles that managed to make it onto their debut full-length manors and that LP overall featured a lot of dance beats really prominent synthesizers sweet songwriting catchy hooks and a really strong falsetto vocal coming from frontman Michael Angelico's and to be completely honest I never really got into this LP never really quite got this album for one I just thought there was so much indie pop released that year that that was more enjoyable like from st. Vincent the panes being pure at heart girls Phoenix and and Mika Chu and in comparison with those artists even Phoenix to me Passion Pit feels just way too just friendly I just don't feel like Passion Pit was offering me much in the way of adventure I do feel like the band was kind of ambitious with some of its instrumentation and how they composed instruments around their pop songs I also liked how they would experiment a bit with vocal samples in their tracks too but the really ultra sweet attitude and the whoa-ohh choruses just kind of killed it for me and you know I'm not against happy music I'm really not if it comes off feeling kind of natural or organic but this LP and just passion pit in general to me just has the feeling of just forcing happiness as hard as possible it's like a happiness dictatorship or just like being in a cult where every single member is staring at you like see it gets creepy after a while and to be honest on manners Angelico's fall said it was really grading on my ears there are so many points on this LP where he just does not feel in control of his falsetto vocal and yet he continues to sing in that register even though he's kind of weaving in and out of pitch I just don't really get much from him as a vocalist but I still do admire the band's unrelenting devotion to all sounds sugary it's playful music and I do like playful music but but I can't help but feel like Passion Pit does not want to play as rough as I usually like to now on gossamer passion pit is really searching for and finding new ways to take their usually giddy sound and style and elevating it to just astronomical levels there's just way more space sounds and just sighs overall with the music on this LP it's just a really gargantuan presentation with very vivid colors pushing play on this thing is like getting instantaneously teleported to Teletubby land with cotton candy clouds and then the smiling baby Sun everything is there and it's not really the songs I have a huge issue with it's the aesthetic because for the most part the songs on here can be pretty good well composed well written for one the song love is greed is a really catchy song and it has a kind of cleverness to the lyrics there's a nice structure to this song and a lot of other songs on this LP which gives every track a really nice momentum it has its highs it has its lows however I feel like I could get into some of these tracks so much easier if so many of them were not performed with this chorus vocal style that just has the the vapid positivity of like a Christian after-school special produced in the 90s but I guess there is a somewhat interesting juxtaposition happening on nearly every single one of these songs you do get in upbeat sound from the music and from the vocal delivery - but the lyrics themselves a lot of times can display some really personal and emotional suffering in a way I guess it's great that Angelico's can take something sad and kind of find a silver lining in and make enough beat track about it but there are some parts where I feel like passion pits really sweet musical style makes some of the sadder emotions on this LP feel kind of ridiculous like the buildup on the bridge with song carried away we've all got something to say at about that point I imagine somebody cueing the dancing animals and smiling flowers however there are some parts on this LP where things are slightly toned-down and it makes the songs so much more palatable like a song constant conversation which is kind of the slow jam on this LP I really like the groove and the closer on the song is actually I think the only legitimate ly sad sounding track on this album that is matched pretty well with it's sadder but on on my way on the hook has a wonderful chord progression that to me shows that with this album Passion Pit has become musically a little more refined and I feel like the falsetto vocals on this album have become a little bit more refined - they're better performed on this album there's more pitch control on them as well I can appreciate improvement like that as well as the instrumental flourishes that I think are very colorful throughout these songs - but still as catchy and as melodic as some of these songs can be I just don't connect with a lot of them emotionally I just find the the attitude the upbeat attitude on this album to be incredibly unrealistic even if there is a morsel of sadness kind of coloring the background of it so overall as I listen to it again and again I did end up liking this LP though not a lot kind of feeling a decent - strong six on this LP I know a lot of you guys are crazy for this album so let me know what you think it do you love it do you hate it why and what should I review next remember the good comment and the great rate but only the strong subscribe passion pit gossamer forever [Music] [Music]

nothing stays the same nothing hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music and it's time for a review knock mystia silencing machine this is an illinois band that has been added for quite a few years released quite a few LPS and they pretty much have a rotating cast of band members that is fronted by the main brain of the group Blake Judd a.k.a centrist why the ominous stage name well not miss tiem is a metal band one that is hugely influenced by the strain of black metal that was coming out of places like Norway in the 90s groups such as darkthrone Gorgoroth mayhem and influence shows in the band's retched style vocals the lo-fi production on their earlier releases and of course the chord progressions that they choose to play with - but in the late 2000s the band started experimenting a bit more with the sounds of black metal including instrumentation that was not exactly considered kosher for this style like saxophone in their records they have even incorporated elements of industrial music psychedelic rock - and the band's creative approach has been met with much positivity from fans and critics alike especially when it comes to the band's 2006 LP instinct decay and the band continues to define themselves with their less than cult approach with subsequent albums which they have named in volumes such as black metal part 1 & 2 metal being any ddle as if you are meddling with something in this case the original blueprint of black metal making the titles on albums like these the cutest play on words in the whole genre of black metal now unless you've been living under a you already know that adventurous and American offshoots of the black metal style have been pretty popular as of late in independent music we're not miss diem fits in the current spectrum of of American black metal to me despite being pretty experimental the band is incredibly no-bullshit yes there's a lot of sound effects and instrumentation on this LP that you would not normally find on a black metal album but it's incorporated so subtly to the point where it's really the band's energy production force and just really melodic and catchy songwriting that that steals the show which to me makes knock miss diem not just a black metal band but a band that just writes really solid songs under a black metal guys for example the harmonized guitar solos and just the really massive epic and emotional riffs on the end of lepers of destitution would sound great finishing off a rock song of any breed and the changes the band makes to the track over the course of its eight minutes really justifies that length and I love the really robotic vocal effects that are on that track as well seems like something that would not work on paper in this style of metal but here in a first hand it works in black metal or not no matter what way you slice it the song borrowed hope and broken dreams extremely catchy song a really dark and moody track that skips on the blast beats and instead emphasizes these really melodic guitar leads some tortured chords and a zany synthesizer that that feels kind of weird but doesn't really take away from the overall attitude of the song tracks like I wait in Hell give me the grave and reduced to ashes are extremely catchy too and that reduced to ashes track really reminds me of why I love black metal because that song is just filled with chords that that really call back to that romance era kind of composition and of course it's mixed together with this really Ross these dark just disgusting vocals I just love that mix of beauty and horror that black metal when it's great brands there's a nice variety among these tracks too you have your faster tracks you have your mid paced tracks and of course you have your really kind of slow bellowing more atmospheric tracks that really go for a big presentation it would have out a hitch the tracks on here have distinct hooks and the chord progressions a lot of weird sound effects on some of these tracks - they're really grabbed my attention a lot like the title track that has these panning effects on the drums that really give you know just a just a unique flavor to the song there's some tracks that stand out for their instrumentation like the closer which I think has a glockenspiel on it there's just a very pretty twinkly melody on that track that I like a lot and there's an array of synth textures too on these songs the only gripes that I have is that sometimes the experimentation on this LP goes a little bit too far to the point where a track and kind of feel ridiculous like on the song decimation annihilation which has these skipping synthesizers kind of pulsating in the midst of just this black metal mess and the drum beat would feel maybe much more at home behind a polka song the trick kind of hits me as being a little distracting but I'm gonna be revisiting this LP because I think it's great and maybe it will grow on me we'll see and what's funny is that is the only song on this album that really kind of takes a slightly industrial route knock miss diem doesn't really embrace that style and in a big way on this album and it's surprising not only because that sound has shown up on previous LPS but it was even on the single that was released before this album that singled the a side and the B side actually do not make it onto this LP and they may have made a nice addition to silencing Machine another downside is that sometimes the experimentations on this thing can't be so subtle that a song can feel a bit in conspicuous a lot like the opening track which is slightly underwhelming and a little bit too basic for me considering that there are so many songs after it especially in the middle and the end of this album that are so awesome and just unique so overall for me this LP is well written it's memorable it's creative things outside the torture chamber as it were uniquely hooky for a black metal album and and very melodic for me a lot like that Agalloch an album marrow of the spirit incredibly easy to get into but there's enough going on enough detail that revisiting this LP is worth it kind of feeling a decent - strong 8 on this album what did you guys think of it did you love it did you hey why and what should I review next remember the good comment and the great rate but only the strong subscribed anthony Fantana knock miss diem forever

Hey it's track review hi everyone Anthony Fantana here entry into internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for track reviews where we talk about the latest in everything because i'm badass someone a new album announced on the way tracklist is out cover art is out the title of this thing centipede Hertz Hz Hertz I imagine it's Hertz the unit of measurement that is typically used for audio purposes in terms of cycles in this forthcoming animal collective LP is looking at a September release on Domino Records thought the band would kind of draw it out a little bit further maybe tease toward the album a bit more but September right around the corner now these guys are easily right now one of the most celebrated contemporary groups and experimental music and in neo psychedelia delia doo ba da and they have tons of hardcore fans who not only just love most of their albums but but also enjoy the side projects that have come out of Animal Collective as well now the band also came out with another single recently honeycomb with the b-side Gotham unfortunately those tracks will not be making it onto the new animal collective LP although I did review it you can find that review below very positive review great song but like I said this track review is going to focus on this new animal collective track which has been titled today's supernatural and the first thing I notice on this track the first thing I'm sure any Animal Collective fan is going to notice is just a V ter is on vocals and seems to be really kind of taking over the songwriting and the energy of this track as well something that was real kind of vacant from Meriweather post pavilion which did bring that album a different flavor made it more accessible because a bee does tend to be the more abrasive of the two major songwriting figures in Animal Collective AV tere and panda bear so Amy really brings back animal collectives wild side on this track bringing things back to a more strawberry jam kind of feel but not nearly as raw and chaotic as the stuff animal collective was putting out around that time they're still sounding pretty I guess well recorded pretty clean though this track is really in your face with a bee screaming and just a really a lot of percussion really kind of intricate Polly rhythms and the bright shops synthesizers playing these burning chords and he's zany arpeggios despite all that this track is is pretty readable and I would say pretty easy to get into I love that this track is not only in three but it really rocks hard on this 3/4 time you do get stubble and really nice manipulations of this rhythm in the background and what also kind of brings change in and progression to this track is all the weird sound effects that kind of interject as a bees versus switch from one to another and of course there are all these strange echoes and just vocal manipulations to his voice as well that just bring another element of weird sounds this track has some intense verses and and easily one of the I guess shortest hooks to ever be on an animal collective song Animal Collective is just great at drawing up these really weird calls and chants and just making them incredibly catchy come on and I'm not 100% sure exactly what this song is about I've been reading the lyrics and maybe the subject of this song is something that we could talk about in the comments a little bit but I do feel like Animal Collective brings that same surprising level of an abstract lyricism this time around - with lines like because you're all the sweetest things and side of you what lines like that do make me tilt my head a little bit but it's a bit of a mind bender whenever I try to make sense of exactly what that could possibly mean and what's funny is that line is a bit of a mantra on this track it's actually a part of a chorus on the album so you're not only getting that as the only chorus you kind of get two choruses for the price of one if you would allow such a short weird chant to be classified as a chorus I guess and I can't really say anything else about this track I just think it's a great frigging song it's got me really excited to hear this new animal collective album like I said it kind of goes back to that strawberry jam kind of feel but with maybe a bit more refinement to it just once again Animal Collective comes forward with a track that has personality interesting structure strange unique sound effects swirling around the instrumentation itself and lots of personality which comes mainly from a visa vocals which I will say are freaking great on this track he just has such a guess an aggressive punk rock esque kind of spirit feeling a little bit of love for this track I can't wait to kind of listen to it more up to the point
