arm hi everyone Anthony Fantino here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review guardian alien see the world given to a one love entity if I am correct this is the Brooklyn band's sophomore LP and their first for thrill jockey records and the reason this project caught my attention is because Greg Fox drummer who you may know from the band liturgy is in this group it's pretty unfortunate that recently Greg had to leave the van liturgy because I guess he wanted to focus on other projects I guess I could understand because he would most definitely mean all the concentration he could muster for this new LP which is essentially 137 minute song what you are going to find on this LP is some pretty progressive strange and and forward-thinking psychedelic rock which features some pretty strong musicianship especially from Greg whose drums are just relentless he brings a lot of the same very fluid intense rolls and fills that made that last literally record such a freaking experience at the very start of this piece it is pretty much a vast atmosphere of guitar freak-outs very metallic drones which sound like they could be coming from a guitar a sitar maybe even a sound bowl or two and there's even some very kind of pleasant chanting in a female voice which throughout the course of this track is being altered sometimes subtly and sometimes not so subtly by a load of effects and though it seems like guardian alien has written some parts out has planned some parts out once I got to about three minutes into this thing it became kind of apparent that in a lot of ways this thing is a jam as I was listening to this one song several things we're going to my mind one I wish the guitars were I guess you know throwing out as much salty as much improvisation and as many interesting ideas as the vocals and the drums were they were really kind of maybe a little too repetitive for me as these guys were jamming out through this track another thing is that the sounds on this album are so friggin good the production is just stellar the sounds are so lush they're just almost kind of tangible the drone on this thing though it does get a little monotonous as the song drags on it is a nice nice drone and pretty much all the instrumentation even as these guys get very chaotic very psychedelic it's very well-balanced very well mixed after the intro the first notable change to me on this song is it about the nine-minute mark the chanting at this point in the song eases up a little bit the guitars are playing different phrases you're getting some extra and different drum fills here and there but keep in mind at this point in the song and throughout this entire track lead drone and just the song in general is in the same key another great change that comes through on this album even though I wish it happened earlier is about the 13 minute mark where the drums break away and once they come back you get them playing in a different time signature and I like that a lot the vocals follow suit and the drone starts to get thickened up with more guitar layers and violin to my least favorite part easily comes at about the 19-minute mark we're all the instrumentation for the most part breaks away and the drone you just get the quiet ambience of the drone which would be cool because there are some points where it gets pretty heavy lots of low-end comes in but all of these field recordings pouring right after and it kind of sounds like they were recorded at the shore you kind of get the ocean lapping against the beach you're getting a little wind noise blowing it to the microphone and there is what kind of sounds like a seagull just incessantly yeah hey I mean to be completely honest the animal sounds don't really add to the moody and very weighty jiron going on behind them it's just kind of distracting and kind of takes me out of the moment I guess the drone lasts about six minutes but right after the instrumentation comes back in and it is very different from what has been going out prior in this song even though it is still in the same key Greg Fox and company really started jamming and rocking on this drone hitting a very very nice groove with some notable intensity something I wish they were doing much earlier past the intro on this thing and that's pretty much a rundown of the experience that I had with this 37 minute track I felt like the performance just the altogether interplay of this thing could have been a bit more intense but I do feel like I came out of this thing with with slightly more pros than cons the instrumentation on this thing is pretty varied and great the recording is stellar I do like the style that these guys are presenting and I think for the most part especially with the track length here they're being pretty ambitious and I did like most the ideas that they presented throughout this Jam I just feel like they structured this one song in such a way where these ideas feel to say me say me to be exciting whenever you're presented with with a new one I guess so overall I do kind of feel like a decent too strong six on this LP definitely not a favorite of mine for the year but don't don't just pass this up because I didn't fall in love with it if you guys have listened to this thing what did you think did you like it did you hate it why what should I review next and remember the good comment and the great rate but only the strong subscribe Anthony Fantana guardian alien forever

it's track review hi everyone Anthony Fantana here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for track reviews where we talk about the latest rock pop electronic and experimental music as well as maybe some hip hop and metal from time to time of the into maybe also major label dependent persuasion and the reason I'm doing this track review is because the indeed electronic duo consisting of Alice glass and Ethan cath known as Crystal Castles as a new track out titled plague recently there has been talk with Crystal Castles of a new LP that they've been recording and over the course of time that I've been following Crystal Castles there have been some ups and some towns while I do love Crystal Castles debut LP I am slightly underwhelmed by the second and to me Crystal Castles debut album was fun it was bouncy it was just really interesting multi-layered and and multi-textured alternative indie electronic pop dance I really love the mixtures of sounds and styles on this album you do get straight dance tunes really short poppy electronic motifs as well as tracks that have more of a shoegaze direction to them - and to pull all of these things together ethan cath will drum up ethereal sounds distorted sounds 8-bit quality audio as well and of course Alice glasses vocals do have a lot to offer to the album - while I don't think she is the greatest vocalist in a traditional sense I do think that she has a lot of personality on a lot of tracks between Crystal Castles first and second LP you'll catch her performing these very sharp girly shouted vocals that that are very attention demanding and I think her vocals can sometimes have an element of cockiness to them that I like a lot and Crystal Castles second LP I mean I could understand it still being self-titled because to me it really feels like a continuation of the same theme except maybe a little more or find with it's tracks that having more gargantuan presentation and and one of the best singles of the year it came out 2010 not in love which featured Robert Smith of the Cure on vocals now that we have this new Crystal Castles track now I'm really kind of crossing my fingers and hoping that it leads and just builds up to an album that I love as much as the debut but after listening to this track I'm just not sure that's gonna happen the track starts off with a really the serial introduction these synthesizers are very light but have a reverb on them that makes them feel pretty panoramic and Alice glass is singing over this introduction in a pretty subdued vocal delivery I guess subdued to the point where it feels kind of anonymous and the vocal melody that she sings in this section of the song just feels very forgettable to me I like that the track has a loud soft dynamic to it it's kind of cliche I'm sure a lot of people are gonna point that out but I mean it's one of the better things this song is going for it because when the song does explode for the first time it does kind of feel at least on some level like who acts just this rush of a really sharp bright like blindingly bright synthesizers just pour in and it's a siser tone texture that that if you're a Crystal Castles fan you've heard used on previous tracks the Sinister playing a very rhythmic phrase that is cycling in a very repetitive manner some buzzing bass adds a little bit of low-end underneath that and Alice glasses vocals kind of gets swallowed and in all of this kind of like the initial tracks to drop from the last Crystal Castles album there are just some production choices that really ruin the song for me and keep me from loving it like why are Alice's vocals so buried on this song or with how just low they're mixed and how much reverb has been slapped on them this kind of sounds like a grime song but with more of an apocalyptic edge or something and it's a little frustrating because to me Alice's vocals are the only thing that are changing up and doing something different at the 150 mark in this song you have pretty much heard everything that this instrumental has to offer to you and it's five minutes long I like the textures and the sounds coming through on the very ethereal interlude around the the second third of the track but it's not so interesting that it makes me interested to hear the last section of the instrumental which is just kind of like a copy and paste job of the previous section of the instrumental I also think the song comes with a pretty obvious mood change too this is definitely one of the angsty ER and darker songs that I've heard Crystal Castles put out and while I didn't really love the execution with the production maybe a darker album from them this time around would be kind of interesting so overall I didn't really care for this track to be completely honest I probably will not be listening to it again until Crystal Castles next album finally comes out and that's it what did you guys think of this track did you love it did you hate it why and what should I review next remember the good comment the great rate and only the strong subscribe Anthony Fantana Crystal Castles forever

hello everyone Anthony Fantana here internets busiest music nerd and it's time for your review purity ring shrines purity ring is a duo consisting of megan james vocalist and and i assume just on the production and this is the debut LP from this synth pop project that caused quite a stir with some ethereal adorable singles one of which belly's peak was one of my favorite singles of last year and both of those singles from 2011 have made it onto this new LP and the remaining nine tracks on this album pretty much follow the stylistic suit set by those singles now purity ring's approach to synthesizer pop is pretty familiar but still different enough to kind of be worth buzzing about without I guess kind of reading it three months from now the songs on this thing feature very heavy atmospheric slow-paced synthesizers and very spacious beats that take a lot of cues from chopped and screwed style hip hop production as well as some southern hip hop - with very kind of trap style snares and hi-hats rattling throughout a lot of these tracks but the songs overall do not come off as dark as I guess you would assume given that those two things are pretty much in every song and the reason the songs on here aren't really brooding it is Megan James voice keeps purity ring's songs from just going too deep into the abyss Megan's voice has a very kind of childlike tambour to it it feels very young feels very girly even on a more sensitive track on this album cartography Megan's voice still maintains a kind of I guess cutesy quality to it I feel like her does bring a somewhat I guess unique sound to pure earring style but is kind of a double-edged sword for me the vocals can be a little monotonous one-dimensional Meghan's range is not all that far and most of her vocal melodies tend to kind of sound very say me say me and emotionally I feel like many of her vocal deliveries on these tracks are pretty flat too very kind of disengaged and and repetitive in that way it kind of reminds me of like a JJ album and instrumentally I don't really feel like purity ring has developed its style all that well past the handful of singles that have been released before this LP the singles have the most detailed production unique melodies and catchiest hooks but it's not just that because of that one-dimensional quality that I feel like this album has listening to an entire gauntlet of songs from purity ring does feel a little boring to me it kind of reminds me of that Colts album that got released last year they had songs released prior to that LP the year before that I thought were pretty good but then sitting through an entire album of their material really just did not do it for me I'm sure they share some fans as well but I'm kind of you know digressing at this point purity ring definitely has a more original style and if we can take the the label which house seriously for one second I think they are more enjoyable and better produce than most of the artists who kind of get slapped with that pretty fashionable label I feel like there's a lot to like about the style that purity ring's has going on shrines but the execution the performance of the songs on this LP is just really underwhelming and the songwriting can be kind of hit or miss like the song fine shrine which has some very glossy since a sputtering beat that I like as well as some kind of morbid lyrics that I'm enjoying but the repetitive melodies and just the lack of added details as the song progresses just don't really sit well with me plus the song a lot of songs on here just overall feel pretty lethargic and not in an intoxicating way there are some sharp tunes on this album but just not enough to really make me like the whole thing I think overall pure d-ring really kind of values style over songs and execution I'm very on the fence with this LP kind of feeling a strong five to a light six on it did you guys like it hate it why let me know and remember the good comment the great rate and only the strong subscribe Anthony Fantana purity ring shrines forever [Music] [Music]

I still got nothing hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review nod their tongues his scatological scatology this is the netherlands-based solo project of multi-instrumentalist maurice i believe his name is pronounced and this project takes a lot of inspiration from black metal nah their tongues essentially borrows black metals trademark distortion tremolo guitar picking retched vocals blast beats as well to create some very vile sounds that are fronted with equally vile album covers hey and a lot of mother tongues tracks are built on ambien interludes instrumental interludes drones noise escapes atmosphere is very essential to the neither tongues formula which is why on so many of this projects previous LPS clear song structures kind of get thrown out the window in favor of creating something that is more like a soundtrack for a long twisted staircase down to hell the sounds on and almost any another tongue's LP are not welcoming by any means however the project looks to add depth to the ugliness on the tracks of its albums by bringing all of this extra instrumentation into the mix real horns and strings and and piano and for the most part this extra instrumentation is arranged impressively bringing some nice musical chops to the chaos now it will admit some of the stuff that comes out of this project can get kind of campy whether it be like the sound effect of chains rattling or people choking or tormented screams ultimately what you were going to hear with a na their tongues release is something that is authentically disturbing now over the years and other tongues has proved itself to be a pretty prolific project releasing sometimes three albums in one year now maybe a scatological scatology is not neither tongues most fear inducing moment on record but i do think it's kind of their most accessible relatively now stylistically this LP feels way more straightforward than most nah their tongues releases really relying on much more of a metal momentum to get things kind of moving they're a lot more blast beats on this LP while there are still a lot of noisy and avant-garde and some I guess noise scape moments on this LP I think this album presents a change that hardcore fans are pretty much going to perceive as being just straight-up black metal and I think the upside to this change that is going on with this LP is that now their tongues is is definitely more of an assault on the ears and it's an assault with very little relief it's not like the the very ugly tension on this album builds up to a catchy climax or really memorable melody or anything like that there's no happy ending to this thing this album's measure of success is basically in forcing you to watch the world burn just kind of take a break stop and smell the corpses does any specific moment on this album do that better than any other moment I can't really say and that's mostly because the level of neurosis on the music from this album is just so watertight when I listen to these tracks which can number from four to ten minutes I do get a nice sense of progression I'm not getting all too much repetition nothing really I've got nothing I've got nothing hi everyone Anthony Fantana here Internet's busiest music nerd and it is time for a review tonight self titled tonight EP tonight is the collaborative project of two up-and-coming electronic music producers from the UK Hudson Mohawke and Lunas I am much more at a bit of an edited I am much more familiar with the former than the latter and the five tracks on this EP are pretty much a mixture of I want to say trap rapped style hip hop instrumentals combined with some pretty recent strains of electronic dance music including future garage and dubstep and these styles are mixed together with the kind of unapologetic audacity that you would expect from somebody who is producing music like far into the future this EP really has no sense of oh these things are separate they should be separated they're different and that's part of the reason I love the internet because when a new sound or style kind of comes out of the blue comes out of nowhere before it even really gets a complete chance to really root itself into a single geographical area or culture everybody around the world is experimenting with it and really weird fusions and experiments can happen and turn into snowballing trends before people or critics really get the opportunity to stomp out the fire and start wagging their fingers screening gimmick gimmick so this is a pretty short EP is five tracks one after another it's just straight bangers bangers burners when I say the beats on this EP bang I mean it this is probably going to be the most hyped up 2012 based music you've heard there's not a single song on this EP that I could sit through sitting still to go back to the musical influences on this thing the trap rap hip-hop style is definitely the most prominent of all of them you do get the kinds of build ups and drops that you would expect from light a waka flocka flame beat or something like that you get those rattling high hats and snare drums that are just relentless at some points on this thing but some of the drops on this EP do have kind of a dubstep flavor to them and a few tracks on here kind of feature the very relentless vocal sample repetitions that you would expect more from an electronic music production coming from the UK which of course is rooted back in Juke and ghetto house if I have to have the lineage spelled out for me one more time I'm going to throw up in my mouth and have to swallow it because throwing up on camera is gross but on the track higher ground I really love how the vocal repetitions on that track are executed they are just so unrelenting it may be the most obnoxious thing you have ever heard for some people but for me it just really adds to the the energy of the track and the bass kicks on on this track and and others on this EP have very bold and clear hip-hop style to them as well the low-end on this EP is stellar you are doing yourself no favors by listening to this through like some earbuds or are just laptop speakers get a system you will most likely be able to pull out the influences that build the songs on this EP very easily what makes these guys different from other producers working with similar hybrids is how zany and just insane the colors and and samples and textures are that these guys work with on on this EP this is almost like psychedelic neon colored trap rap instrumentals the track buggin has really hard beats but they are slathered in reverb and they're like samples of this baby playing throughout the track going there all these bubbles popping in the beat too of course the scents are really weird there are all sorts of heavy the size was on the track higher ground to that I like a lot that sound like party horns burnt my remember and the track easy-easy has a load of weird crap mixed into the beat one sample kind of sounds like a car crashing which is played over and over I kind of hear a gun cocking these high-pitched vocal samples that sort of interject occasionally going yeah there are a lot of strange textures and samples on this EP but Hudson Mohawke and Lunas just take these sounds and they chop them loop them manipulate them with such an attention to detail how could the production shops on this EP not be recognized these tracks on this EP really do kind of appeal to those two sides of my brain and I love music like that that really not only just makes me react emotionally very quickly but I can also just sit back and think oh hmm derp derp hmm derp and there is a nice range of variation between these five tracks as well not only in terms of mood but in terms of just I guess style and sound some tracks rely more on vocal samples others just the beat and some synthesizers their moments like the first track that are pretty atmospheric and kind of Moody while others are very playful flamboyant experimental and just all-around engaging though this EP is short to me it is very satisfying I wish the first track were longer but that's really the only major issue I have with it I personally think it is very awesome and refreshing to hear electronic music like this that takes on such a heavy hip-hop influence and is so well produced but does not take itself too seriously it's just this really fun and catchy brand of neon colored aggression that I like a lot I'm feeling a light too decent 9 on this EP what do you think of it you have heard it love it hate it why let me know remember the good comment the great rate and only the strong subscribe tonight self-titled EP rapper [Music]

and it's time for a quick little album review Mission of Burma unsound this is the latest LP from Boston an experimental rock and post-punk outfit Mission of Burma a group whose early stuff I love to these releases some of my favorites ever back in the day Mission of Burma had a lot of energy some real Punk spirit but they were very heady band as well very cerebral with how they would experiment with their to their songs they would fuss with a weird time to signature or a strange groove or some syncopation and a track they would load a song with weird sound effects and and tape loops thanks to the help of Martin Swope kind of the fourth member of the group who pretty much would do his thing offstage or just add kind of strange sounds along with the band in post-production certainly for their time these guys were very unique very bold very weird but they wrote songs that were accessible that were kind of catchy loaded with fresh sounds that would just stick upon first contact sadly the band really only thrived for about four years the band's guitarist and Co frontman coast songwriter Roger Miller had tinnitus he kind of had to bow out ohayo I but 19 years later they kind of came back with a vengeance started touring again got on Matador records started putting out albums again that were pretty well received by critics by fans and and by people who were hearing about them for the first time - but as happy as I am that the band got back together when it comes to the first two full-length LPS that these guys are released after their hiatus I mean I kind of feel like I'm in bizarro world a little bit because of how well-received they were and I was not hot on them at all especially on the LP on off on which to me was was really kind of clean and and overproduced for these guys and I was kind of finding less strange sound effects on these records to just less mind-bending moments in 2009 the band came out with the sound the speed the light and I actually liked this record quite a bit the band changed their production it sounds like they are recording in the in the same manner they were back in the 80s with this record I saw Mission of Burma kind of not only embracing their older sound but continuing to advance it and experiment with it as if the hiatus had never happened now on this new LP Mission of Burma continues to kind of perform their tracks in the raw really letting that interplay flow and letting the the chaos occur much in the same way that the band did on their live LP but of course they have a more focused studio sound to it this thing is best songs the next track semi pseudo sort of plan has a classic Burma feel to it too but Clint is fronting this track and if you've never heard this band before you'll kind of get a grip of the two songwriting styles of Roger Miller and Clint Connolly on this particular track yeah it is catchy er it is easier on the ears and it's because he has the tendency to write songs that are more anthemic and approachable and that's the dynamic that they kind of have been switching back and forth between for years but this is the first LP where I feel like they're really kind of toy with that dynamic and break it a bit because during the songwriting process this album were really the performance process the recording process of this album instruments were switched and members had to write songs on sectionals and mourning the guitars the bass the vocals are there but they do not seem to be I guess sort of played in the way that you would expect for a mission of Burma especially the guitars which descending blues rock guitar leads that does sound like they could have been out of classic rock tunes there's also a trumpet on the end of that track and multi-layered trumpets on the track after that as well I think the trumpet is and could be a great addition to mission of Burma's music but I feel like mixed wives they weren't blended in all that well for the most part this album keeps me engaged sonically especially on tracks like hi-fi where the band kind of satirizes people who kind of in take most of their their media I guess via really tiny screens or very tiny laptop speakers where everything kind of either looks or just sounds like crap meanwhile there's a lead vocal over this singing through what seems like the speaker on a cell phone it's kind of annoying but it's I was so young hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review rec and reference no youth these guys are an experimental rock project they are pretty anonymous from what I understand and this is their sophomore LP e and this LP doesn't really fall into one set style or genre instead these guys kind of jump all over the place and blend a series of things together meanwhile making their own sort of unique direction maybe even some indie rock is mixed in there as well but the greatest fee of this entire LP is that it creates such a noisy abrasive really kind of disturbing atmosphere with no guitars whatsoever and I was pretty stunned because on first listen with this LP I could have sworn that I had heard some guitars but after revisiting with it yeah it's it's pretty clear this this album is comprised of nothing but since and samples as well as drums and vocals and even though synthesizers are no stranger to any of the genres that these guys experiment with to use them exclusively has led some really unique hellish and twisted sounds so if you do like your music to be the sonic representation of dancing and singing teddy bear that that loves to cuddle on cold winter nights you may want to listen to another album because this is a legitimately creepy thing I would go as far as to stay freaky and as I was relisting and re listening to it I did feel kind of feelings of paranoia creeping in parts of this album really do kind of sound like the soundtrack to a murder or at least an abduction now the sounds on this LP are stellar it's basically where rec and reference kind of finds a way to beat competition the LP opens up with this really sharp echoey metallic rattle it sounds like a transformer on top top of a telephone pole as exploded but this LP is not just random noise after random noise these guys do figure out a way to take the noises they create and incorporate them effectively into their songs like the spoken-word vocals sound great but they can be kind of hit or miss as well as the singing vocals and I guess my issue would be is that they fall a little flat and that they don't really match the creepiness or the intensity of the music that they're singing over and get kind of lost in the haze I end up tuning them out and they don't really bring a lot of personality to the track I guess and maybe even to a slight degree kill the the very disturbing vibe I guess another gripe I have with this LP is the songwriting the song structuring most of the songs on here range from about three to four minutes but they feel so much shorter to me sometimes because I guess they do take a while to kind of pick up momentum and once they grab it it's not all too long before the ending is right there and there are just some songs out here that I just wish were longer for music this strange in this noisy McKey and reference definitely likes to kind of keep things brief I guess because a lot of these tracks do come off is just kind of being like motifs but to kind of continue on the songwriting there are some really great chord progressions if not drones on this album like the track cannot and obedience I am really impressed with the musicality of some of these songs too overall I was pretty impressed with this LP I think it's a great album for an up-and-coming group there are those elements in the songwriting and in the vocal delivery that do feel a little weak to me but I think it's fantastic that these guys can blend so many genres together have a track that feels more black band kind of finds themselves in the midst of an interesting progression interesting but not completely unique because Baroness on this LP is going soft her kind of walking down the same path heavy music heavyweights such as Mastodon and torch have walked down with their new LPS both of which are the most accessible in their respective discographies now despite pulling together a series of tracks that are easily some of the sweetest this band has ever produced Baroness has still not let go of their sense of ambition their knack for epic presentations because this thing is a double album seventy-six minutes 18 tracks across these 18 tracks there's quite a bit of love variety there are some loud pounding riffs quiet acoustic interludes softer rock tracks and pretty climactic builds there are a lot of changes in mood on this LP and there are some progressive elements as well but I'm not about to tag this as a progressive rock album there are tracks on here like take my bones away this guy's an R&B singer and a member of the California rap collective Odd Future then I would say with releasing very little material he has pretty much proven himself to be the most talented and and tortured and drug-addled version of Michael Jackson where Frank Ocean by contrast is much more of a Stevie Wonder Martin Gaye kind of guy now when it comes to nostalgia ultra a lot of people have asked me to review it for sure it's an alternative to the commercial art bita ruled the airwaves when I was a kid but it didn't really hit me as being unique or different enough to be all that production I wanted is here Plus this LP right out of the gate is getting a release on 4ad records on paper some great things are occurring but in fact I wanted from this album is not here at least on hi everyone Anthony Fantan oh here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for an EP review H sick or herb sicca with coca d this guy is a juke and and footwork music producer both styles of electronic music originated from Chicago and have been as of late seeing a relatively decent amount of underground success the genres are being combined and and recognized internationally among many different producers labels like planet mu and warp or picking up records that that either play in these Styles combine them or just experiment with them and this style for the most part is characterized by a lot of space between the bass kicks in these productions really kind of letting those hang in the back and allowing the treble elements of the rhythms to kind of drive things the hi-hats the snares and these high hats and snares are produced to be just really relentless having very jittery scary very kind of rattling quality to them and these snare and hi-hat patterns can be really dizzying and when a producer in these styles is great they're in a constant state of flux and that change that hi hats and these snares are always going through brings a real sense of progression to the songs of course all these elements are paired with some really fast tempos and at times some repetitive looping vocal samples which comes from the Juke side by side of the hybrid that a lot of producers are pulling together which of course borrows even further back from ghetto house but if you are familiar with electronic music styles like break beat and drum and bass jungle I don't feel like this is going to be that difficult into music in this style because just like those styles there are just patterns flying at you from every direction it's just a different kind of pattern a different kind of groove and I feel like herb sicca definitely has his own spin on this groove because even though there are some artists out there representing the style of music in the raw tracks man for example curve kind of brings a bunch of African elements into his music and kind of claims an interesting stake of musical property though artists like Africa high tech have come in the track you don't need a pair of shoes has a pretty dark chord progression to and the tempo feels a little bit slower on that track leaving more space for just the the hi-hats and the snares to just go even wilder I love all the indescribable noises just swirling around that song the really nice sub bass tones rumbling throughout the song too and the fourth song on here manages to kind of cut the tempo down even more i would say half as to some great arpeggios and these metallic chimes to them now as far as some quick downsides the track on here co energy though it is colorfully produced like of get me moving and and kind of thinking at the same time just the myriad of sounds and intricate layers that I'm hearing all at once but others just do feel a bit underwhelming I guess it is a bit short it does kind of feel like there is still some room for development in terms of her sikka really defining his style with his African take on these genres of electronic music though the good news ooh baby baby it's really hot outside it's all inside huh hi everyone Anthony fan tanto here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review The Dirty Projectors swing low Magellan Dirty Projectors is the Brooklyn based experimental indie pop project fronted by singer/songwriter and guitar player David long stress if I'm correct this is their seventh full-length LP and this band is known for its really bold strange and then kind of interesting style and fans longtime fans of the band can expect to hear a lot of that on this album well maybe not a lot maybe more like like some such as David long strength very adventurous guitar melodies and his his beautifully embellished chord progressions there's just a lot of virtuosity in his guitar playing if you love hearing technical and and very beautiful very refined guitar playing definitely check out what he does you can also expect to hear some very tight female vocal harmonies from amber Kaufman and angel Dara Dorian launcher its vocals to have a very kind of unique quality to them they're they're very strange sometimes feeling very sour too you know I could really go on because there are so many things that make Dirty Projectors so different from your average band and really it kind of depends on what album you're listening to as well but if there was a change in the overall formula in Dirty Projectors sound on this new LP it's really that the band kind of embraced a real sense of simplicity on swing low magellan the song structures on this thing art is long or is winding amber and angels vocal harmonies aren't even really utilized as much on this LP as they were on Dirty Projectors previous couple they're not as intrusive really kind of hanging in the background most of the time unless you have a female vocal singing lead and then on top of that the intricate drumming that that has been pretty prominent on Dirty Projectors last LP has kind of been replaced by much more simple rhythms and if you're not hearing a drum you will hear an electric beat or even some kind of unsatisfying handclaps and the instrumentation itself is is not even really that lavish or adventurous as colorful as laird even when something like a string section does manage to pop into a track it's not really orchestrated with as much imagination as what's been put on previous projectors LPS I feel like the band with this album started on a very straightforward path and when they came out on the other side at the end of the path all they had to show for it was a more toned down version of their usual sound I don't think the band has gotten more accessible I mean yeah sure things are a little simpler but David long struts voice the melodies he writes the vocal harmonies between amber and Angel the strange grooves and time signatures and and long strips very surreal lyrics are still going to be kind of a speed bump for people who have not heard of this band before it's not like swing low Magellan has some kind of super catchy crossover pop appeal I do think there are some great tracks on here though the track impregnable question is an amazing piano ballad beautiful love song the title track on here has a very warm bare-bones kind of Velvet Underground quality to it and the song the gun has no trigger the first single off of this LP has this amazing climax to it on the chorus and I think that song out of all of these on here has the most interesting and and surreal lyrics actually for the most part I think the songs on this album are very good it's that the Dirty Projectors don't really color them or flesh them out or detail them the way a hardcore fan would expect the production isn't even that good to the guitars can be I guess a little muddy sometimes if they don't really feel like they have any crunch any push especially when they get loud that's when they get a little rough the electronic beats on this thing are very flat colorless lifeless and even the vocals and the vocal harmonies come off a little you know kind of muddy as well and the reverb that's on the vocals sometimes the instrumentation too is just very kind of bare bones basic and cheap I would bet that the production's budget on this thing is the smallest Dirty Projectors have worked with since the glaad fact and I don't feel like I would be so underwhelmed by this album if Dirty Projectors previous LPS hadn't been so grand and in scope and Colour and imagination don't be surprised if swing low magellan is not as rewarding with repeated listens as at least their previous four albums I'm feeling a light too decent 6 on this thing what did you guys think of it did you love it did you hate it why and what should I review next you have any Fantana Dirty Projectors forever [Music] Oh hi everyone Anthony Phan Tiano here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review death spell Omega drought these guys are a French band kind of got its start playing black metal in the doing that they have been releasing some of the most interesting albums and EPS in black metal modern black metal peer hear hear hear hear it now when it comes to progressive and technical metal I tend to be very picky and you know it's only because a lot of bands that get labeled as being progressive or technical put together really bland lifeless plastic sounding recordings that really just don't sound good doesn't sound like I'm listening to a band it just kind of sounds like I'm listening to a machine or something I think I think abut death spell Omega steps away from all of that thankfully and just one track after another track delivers these really raw performances of twisting and sometimes nearly indecipherable metal songs and I really love the sound of the music on this EP the drums sound great they're really clear they're feeling so real so tangible so crisp you really get a sense of the way the kit sounds the guitars are really rugged they're textured they're rich sometimes there's a really dramatic Beauty to them like in the intro track which is very I guess kind of spacious a lot like an earth song the guitars are also fit for playing these extremely frenetic and fast riffs that cannot seem to really kind of sit still in a single groove for all too long constantly changing speed and direct and sometimes no real clear song structure comes out of the chaos that these guys are workers trading you get these really sour dissonant black metal chords you get the intricate drums and in grooves rhythms fills and on top of all of that these extremely just gruesome lead vocals throaty and the way that they're delivered throughout much of death spell omegas discography you don't really get a sense of singing as much as you do narration which isn't a surprise considering that these guys with their last full-length album finished a conceptual trilogy based on the theological relationship between God Satan and man technically and and compositionally and sonically production was there's a lot to praise however their music is not the easiest pill to swallow and believe it or not this album in the band's new EP are two of the most accessible releases in their discography for one this EP kind of breaks the mold of death spell Omegas past several eps and is not one or or a few very lengthy songs instead you get a grouping of six tracks that range from a minute thirty Seconds to foreign change like I said the opening track is really pretty just dark and moody the track following after fiery serpents though it is changing constantly shifting the riffs are pretty readable the track abrasive swirling murk earns its name easily he tons of drum fills that are nearly impossible to calculate but the improved recording quality that death spell is working with on this new EP actually makes the hectic chaos much easier to make sense of the closing track on here boughs out before I really would have liked it to but not before it starts incorporating a very faint group of chorus vocals that are pretty chilling in a very empathetic chord progression for the most part I feel like these tracks are kind of a continuation of a lot of the sounds that were on para Cletus death spell Omegas definitely not letting go of this more direct approach that they've been dealing with recently but now they're doing it with a better recording that makes them sound amazing this EP is basically a great way for death spell Omega to just say we still have great things coming after we have finished this trilogy and they're teasing toward it with what they're probably going to sound a lot like in the near future with a new LP with one of the best metal a EPS I've heard this year I'm feeling a decent too strong eight on this EP hello my needle drops Anthony Fantan oh here internets busiest music nerd review time hot chips Hot Chip in our heads these guys are an English synth pop band with a strong emphasis on hooks and dance beats this is their fifth full-length LP it's self produced and out on Domino Records they've never really been one of my favorite bands in this style of music but I've always been impressed with the amount of homework that Hot Chip clearly does and has done when it comes to their genre they'll be futzing around with a lot of analogs since on some of their tracks and and the way these sequence them to will really call back to the golden days of synthesizer pop groups like OMD Simple Minds Depeche Mode the Human League new order they clearly have all these old-school influences but they bring a kind of fresh indie sensibility to their songwriting and and that pretty much allows them to get away with so many references to the past without feeling like a direct throwback now when it comes to song and melody writing hot chips approach is extremely simple and consciously so they really try to avoid complications whenever possible and instead shoot for an overwhelming sense of fun I always thought their vocals could use a little bit more personality I guess but they really make up for it for the most part with so many colourful and bouncy synthesizers guitars and rhythms that together just kind of pumped out grooves that I cannot say no to now these guys have been improving their overall sound sound quality production whatever you want to call it from album to album with their previous LP definitely be hermos were fined instrumentally and with this new LP Hot Chip is roughly going for the same sound same approach lots of layered intricate percussion an array of synth textures lots of friendly vocals very quirky attitude and songs that shoot for a variety of aesthetics in in dance music and electronica there's not really a world of change between this LP and their previous one the differences are very subtle maybe this album has more love songs on it but that's about it however I'm not trying to say that the band does not bring variety on this album sonically at least the song night and day is a completely unashamed dancefloor monster that I could see a band like chromeo covering very comfortably and the track nice chains is is very smooth soft and has a beat behind it that I could see being maybe a little bit more comfortable playing in the background of a burial song and the track look at where we are is one of the most legit slow jams of 2012 extremely sexy and the song motion sickness is such a blissful opener the world is round the world is and the part where everything spins I love the lyrics on this track it's really just a beat uplifting opener their songs on here where the backing instrumentation feels like it's influenced by house music and disco - especially the closer on here which I love but maybe slightly goes overboard with some spoken-word vocals kind of bordering in territory like I said there's a variety of songs on this album I could describe everyone as being definitely different and distinct from the others but what I think kind of ties this entire album together and this is something that I think Hot Chip has been getting better at doing with every new album the band's music just has this really sweet light innocent feel to it I could totally put this LP on in front of a six year old without really breaking a sweat or a 60 year old for that mater I'm not trying to insult Hot Chip or say that it's dumbed down or anything like that what I'm trying to illustrate is that I feel the music they make is just so beautifully universal of course that kind of direction is going to warrant some negativity when I put this album on myself I hated it this is just not for me this isn't my mood this is my attitude but the same innocence that was kind of turning me off at first as I listen to the album again and again actually ended up kind of you know melting the ice and made the album enjoyable at the end of the day I felt like a handful of tracks on here were a little underwhelming and maybe a bit too heavy-handed with some repetitive choruses I felt like hot chips for a into a more dubstep influenced rhythm was kind of just just okay if you're looking for a lot of electronic dance pop songs that are as colorful as the cover that you're seeing right here then give this a listen feeling a strong 7 to a like 8 on this but what did you guys think of it did you love it did you hate it why and what should I review next anthony Fantan Oh Hot Chip

it's 2:00 a.m. that's a normal work schedule hi everyone Anthony Fantino here internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a double review ty Segall and white fence hair and ty Segall band slaughterhouse gone see ty go go go go go go go go ty Segall is a california garage rock artist he blew up several years ago back when the sounds of lo-fi rock recordings and garage punk were the hottest sounds that the blogosphere had to offer and at the time I was heading into J retard I was having the black lips but I never really fell too hard for what ty Segall was doing for the most part it was garage punk with a subtle psyche Rock influence he had some really chaotic production too just so friggin noisy and he just fronted his songs with these very over-the-top vocals recorded with just this very very brittle sharp bouncy echo he kind of reminded me of the Oh C's a bit at the time and though I didn't really hate it it just didn't click with me though I do admire the energy that he put into a lot of his tracks he is just a one-man powerhouse he really just kind of cuts his stomach open and dumps his guts all over some of his tracks especially on his 2008 self-titled LP which was really just kind of an experiment in high volumes and just raw guitar drum simplicity ever since this LP I think ty Segall has kind of gone back and reverted a bit to his previous LP horn the unicorn where there was a bit more variety a bit more detailed to some of the songs not every one of them was so loud and noisy and hard-hitting but even though I think ty Segall is being a little easy around the ears these days with some of his solo stuff and you know adding more detail and whatnot he still manages to keep it rough around the edges very fun and very freakish at this point ties it all has over five albums under his belt and you know even though his fans kind of come to expect a certain thing from him he never quite likes to deliver it in the same exact way while he's always wallowing in the world garage rock with a loaf I'd twist to me his albums just are this never-ending exploration of ways to make the sounds of psychedelic rock garage rock and punk just noisier weirder more unsettling wild and sweaty but even though a lot of times music is just rife with this experimentation he never really loses sight of having a good time when it comes to this style of music though it is not as hot now as it was a few years ago on the whole I feel like he's one of the few people out there at this moment who are still bringing some surprises he's really kind of carrying the torch for this kind of stuff now he's at the forefront of the pack with this sound and he's pushed himself there this year with two new releases a collaboration with White Fence and a new album with his ty Segall band the first time he's releasing an album under that title now in regards to the collaboration with White Fence ty Segall and White Fence are cut from roughly the same lo-fi cloth with some noticeable differences the last few White Fence records even though Rock does influence this guy they really kind of left me feeling like he is so much more of a sound experimentalist than a guy who really wants to kind of pound out a rock song that's gonna get fist pumping thinking just bodies jumping out of windows and stage diving and all that good fun time happy good stuff and kind of in theory I could see this collaboration working out really one way tie brings the badass guitar riffs brings the energy White Fence brings the eccentricity the color a little bit of weirdness and in the end you kind of get a group of very colorful detailed oddball garage rock tunes with a psychedelic edge that have got a lot of energy and force behind them and I would say fantasy you know she though this LP is short it makes up for it with a lot of highlights the track I am a game has this really kind of kooky keyboard on it it's a really just tough tense driving garage rock tune with a very slow heavy site rock breakdown and I love how the transition from point A to point B lots of grace interplay there are even more psychedelic elements on the track the black glove slash rag which has some just classic rock gold in the drum fills and the interjecting wailing guitar leads just popping in here and there and the lo-fi feel on the track actually kind of turns the song a little bit into somewhat of a 60s throwback the song is catchy and the vocals on the track just have this really kind of lethargic weird quality to them that really makes this very tried-and-true sound feel mutated and kind of uncomfortable in a memorable and somewhat enjoyable way but if you want to talk about something being mutated listen to the song cry-baby which sounds like a more muscular version of the riff from the Beatles song The Ballad of John and Yoko the song just has everything so freaking loud claustrophobic close to the mic it sounds like a bunch of practice amps with three stomp distortion boxes just turn all the way up playing it once and I don't know it's it's being performed within my skull and it's throbbing plus the song has this badass 50s R&B style boogie woogie piano solo the solo really kind of sounds like it's on cocaine and just really kind of hops in and brings the song to an entirely different level the song scissor people has such hard-hitting guitars really the noisiest track on here and I love how they start playing with the left and right channels with some of the guitar distortion on that track and the last song on here has a great groove and as Tai and White Fence bring the song closer to the finish line it appears more and more kind of like a jam session you know this collaboration has a lot of kind of 60s Kitsch to it but some colorful eccentricities get added along the way of course that awesome ty Segall garage punk energy is thrown into the equation - just a short sweet garage and psychedelic freak out really infectious energy behind hair I feel like the lazy kind of laid-back lethargic vocals do strip a few songs of their personality especially the first and the third track the melodies on those songs it's too hot for an intro still what still oh-oh-oh-oh I'm getting real good at sweating my my needle drops it's time for a review the Smashing Pumpkins Oceania this is the ninth studio LP from famed alternative rock band The Smashing Pumpkins a band who really made their mark on the 1990s with some of the most critically acclaimed albums to come out of that decade the very rough and psychedelic Gish the catchy Aaron and more refined Siamese Dream the epic ambitious double album Mellon Collie and the infinite sadness as well as the not as hot but more goth tinged adore which brought a little bit more electronics into the fold too with the pumpkins music these guys had their lineup changes over the course of their career and they were on a serious streak up until about the 2000s they kind of opened up the millennium with what was supposed to be their last record machina a concept album that was kind of a decent return to their alt rock sound considering that adore definitely left them in a different spot when fans had last heard a studio album from them in the early 2000s death was definitely knocking on the Smashing Pumpkins doorstep and they just kind of called it quits and then after years of side projects solo efforts in 2007 the Smashing Pumpkins decided to get back together with a different lineup Billy Corrigan was there Jimmy Chamberlin was back on drums and the band kind of seemed to return where where they left off with a new album titled zeitgeist and when I say left off you were mocking a left off which had its its pros and it's cons there were definitely some moments on this LP that fell especially heavy but the lyrics left a lot to be desired even though they were kind of taking a surprisingly political shift in in message the guitars are so loud but so just like muddy and and hearing guitars recorded like that is like drinking sour milk Jimmy Chamberlain's drums are just stashed all the way in the back could barely really make out a lot of the subtleties however Billy Corrigan has not given up in refining the pumpkins sound in this phase of their career and recently he's been putting out material as the Smashing Pumpkins with a new lineup and sort of working on this project called tear guard and by kaleidoscope where the pumpkins are kind of putting out songs one by one in small bits and then releasing them as EPS as time moves on but Oceania has kind of interrupted the flow of that project in a way maybe I guess it's supposed to be a part of that series however it's really no secret that the Smashing Pumpkins were not getting all that much attention or success from this new one by one song release format so now we're back to an album format 13 songs in one big bunch and while the Smashing Pumpkins stylistically are not really at the forefront of much of anything anymore they do sound good on this LP they avoid a lot of the older guitar tones and and some of the older riffs something I don't really feel like they tried to do all that much on zeitgeist which in addition to all the other issues made it sound dated though slightly I would say it's a loss of their trademark sound this is I know how you want the Smashing Pumpkins to feel in 2012 now I'm sure there are fans on the internet that are praising this record simply because the band has managed to put out a better album than zeitgeist and for sure that has happened but I would argue that you know this album does function beyond that the songs on this thing bring a mix of both heavy and delicate moments it's multifaceted dimensional just like you would want a Smashing Pumpkins album to be but I do feel like one side of the cell peak goes over better than the other the Achilles heel for me on Oceania are the louder tracks like the opening track on this thing quasar it actually made me want to just turn the album off right from the start though I think it is the loudest riff on this LP it's incredibly tame and just proof that the Smashing Pumpkins are just nowhere near as ferocious as they used to be I feel the same way about the next track on this LP panopticon but I do feel like it goes down easier because it is a more melodic track and focuses on Billy Corgan songwriting a bit more as opposed to just yeah plus the track features all these very rich just beautiful harmonized guitar leads that that pop up on quite a few tracks on here which really bring a very bright quality to this album and then just Smashing Pumpkins sound an aesthetic on this LP in general though there are still those moody spots that you would expect from a pumpkin this album this thing is definitely feeling like a bright blue sky totally cloudless sun is shining air is warm there's a light breeze kind of like that it's like a brand-new day those harmonized guitar leads get really hyped up and played at a faster tempo on the track chimera toward the end of this album and they get played so fast in just such a lively way that it feels like the smashing come they're kind of playing pop-punk like I said just a lot of louder spots on here feel either just weak or a little too sugary where I think this LP gets great are the quieter moments that's where Billy Corgan songwriting really stands out and you start getting those beautiful just breathtaking symphonic rock tracks that call back to some of the best moments on melancholy songs like the Celestials violent Ray's my love is winter one diamond one heart those songs are all next to each other and they're really quite the streak on this LP lots of moody hooks that just burst with heavy guitars and synthesizers lots of melody Billy's voice sounds great the acoustic break on my love is winter freakin rules and sadly after that I kind of feel like this LP falls apart on the title track oceania Billy Corgan songwriting is is great there's a lot of changes in instrumentation but then they try to drag it out to nine minutes and kind of fall short in the process there's a nice acoustic breakdown but then it morphs into this synth rock part that doesn't really go anywhere and just kind of bhau's out fades out before anything interesting really happens it's really a letdown it's kind of like being kicked out of a party after the title track on here I have a hard time describing a lot of the songs on this LP because I feel like they are so nondescript their songs on here that definitely kind of feel like revamped versions of songs that have already been on smash pumpkins albums but are kind of performed with this brighter richer sound that the Smashing Pumpkins are working with right now songs like pale horse and an inkless for sure the final track on this LP is very pretty song it's it's a decent closer and overall I just kind of come away from this album feeling like I said I just heard a brighter more modern version of these Smashing Pumpkins that that I'm used to there are points at this LP that do feel a bit complacent like Billy Corgan is is a little too intent on kind of serving up the same old Smashing Pumpkins sound but just altered ever so slightly and while that has made this album enjoyable for me it really hasn't turned into love I guess all the way through because there are spots on here that do kind of feel like a formulaic bore I'm kind of feeling a decent two strong six on this album which I know you know doesn't seem like that amazing but I'm actually pretty happy about it considering I thought I was gonna go into this album hating it so it was pretty nice for to just kind of turn around on me actually surprise me with some very enjoyable songs that make me look forward to the next Smashing Pumpkins release so what did you guys think of this album did you love it did you hate it why and what should I review next and what do you think of the Smashing Pumpkins at this point in their career and Billy carrying on the name and and all that jazz hmm let me know Anthony Fantana the Smashing Pumpkins [Music]

of unoffensive indie rock sound whose boldest characteristics were probably Emily Haines synth playing and and her singing and metric sound has just grown more and more polished over time and Synthetica is their most polished album yet like the title suggests I get kind of a synthetic feel from some of these tracks for the opening hits and it's very atmospheric it's very glossy the guitars underwater but in Metrix case the the music comes off nowhere near as well produced as well written or kind of performed all that well performed with any energy because a lot of these songs to me just album in about seven years and in the internet age even taking a few years to come out with your new album seems to be becoming a longer and longer time so I think there may be some people watching who aren't necessarily one after % familiar with Fiona Apple her style her work and everything like that but she's the kind of artist who you don't necessarily need to go scope all of her older albums in order to appreciate what she does because she's been so consistent in her sound and her style with album after album just slinging these piano rock tunes backed by drum and acoustic bass and on all of her albums as well including this one Fiona shows that mark of a great songwriter in that she can send a really strong emotional connection with the listener through her music make the emotions feel tangible for the listener even if the story in the song is very personal or difficult to relate to not only does Fiona have this characteristic but I would say she's insanely gifted in this department more than most but her really tense singing over most of her songs you get the sense that she can snap at just about any moment and sometimes she does and she writes very poetic lyrics detailing a myriad of just really nasty situations but for the most part relationships gone sour and sometimes even lays the blame on herself like the song off this album werewolf where Fiona is basically singing about how bad this person is relating them to a shark relating them to a werewolf but then admitting that she provided the bloody wound in the water or the the moon that would actually turn this person into that she teases out the terrible side of this person though characteristics like this are pretty much on every Fiona Apple album there are variations and and I would say the idler-wheel sees her using her usual tropes her usual emotions and bringing them to a new kind of unsettling and disturbing intensity and it's kind of a nice change of pace considering that her last album was really sweet by comparison to her other releases it was a lot poppier than her usual stuff it had the personality that you would expect from a Fiona album but the edge was really taken off by some really sweet and sometimes jazz nice jazzy horn sections and and some baroque strings - I would say the idler-wheel strips things back a bit it has extra instrumentation but it's used subtly for the most part it really subtracts the sugar and I think it's the better for it it's made a more emotionally potent album I'm welcome welcome Welding the sound of the instrumentation on this thing the piano the bass and the drums it's Fiona's usual foundation but it sounds so punchy and modern and crisp on this thing and the performances just sound refreshing and that they have a lot of percussion on here that that kind of tips its hat to jazz there is a track on here where there's a sample of kids yelling and there's another track where it sounds like the percussion is is made of nothing but glass bottles and tin cans the song regret actually has an ominous drone hanging in the background these subtle little sonic editions on almost every track really do separate the songs nicely and bring a different flavor to all the tracks here on the opening track I feel like Fiona is not singing as much as she is acting throughout this song she is just telling this really intense story of these internal emotional battles over these very chilly celeste ports the song daredevil is is kind of about Fiona being sort of personally addicted to emotional extremes and and the music guest on the track captain Steve's another Pro a remember there are a lot of layers of lyrical wordplay making people PE nuts like elephants but throw them in the trunk if they hate though or when Captain Steve says King Arthur when he swung his sword or King author I ain't even used a pen in like a month or four these guys actually come together again on the next track and completely kill it twice the song hard-knock comes right after it's a sadder track on this album has this very depressing descending chord progression that actually reminds me a lot of the song blue from the last roots album but with more of a vintage flavor and Joey badass and and the feature on the track CJ fly another Pro era member kind of trade stories about kind of being caught up in the downward spiral of just hood life with a lot of gritty lyrics and sincerity another few tracks on here kind of Musa where Joey's past his everyday life is at spiration songs like waves snakes and another one of my favorites daily routine which has beautifully produced B even though there are a lot of songs on here that I love there's just too many tracks that I feel are not as impressive just kind of passable the song where it's at just kind of feels really mundane where Joey is describing this kind of party situation that really isn't interesting at all and on the song righteous Minds actually on a few tracks on here Joey will spit with a pretty relentless flow and and bring some pretty dense verses but he's not really performing it with any passion or heart and really kind of sounds on exciting and women can kind of be a so-so subject for Joey to the song pennyroyal which i think was a great song righted which i think is a great song at the very first lyric of the track Joey tells you that it is a love song gone wrong that it is however other tracks like funky hoes and don't front kind of feel like paranoid assumptions about women fueled by a few bad experiences and maybe some general awkwardness with women the last track on here is an 11 minute Posse track featuring pretty much all the pro era crew members and even though it isn't one of my favorites on the album I think it's pretty much a feat that this very young up-and-coming crew actually pulled together such a long Posse track that is worth listening to all the way through overall 1999 to me is a very good tape I feel like some tracks on here definitely feel more well developed than others in terms of wordplay in terms of the hook the lyrical subject matter and the instrumental - there's just a good chunk of songs on here that only feel okay kind of like they're laying back on their boom-bap sound just kind of hoping that alone will make them sound impressive and classic without question I do love the boom bap style that Joey is going for some of my favorite records of all time have been made in it but it's not like I think it's the be-all end-all of hip-hop I think hip hop can go more places than this of course there's room for revivalism but if you're going to go down that road make sure the songs themselves are more well groomed and bring some more original production of the table that's all feeling a decent too strong 7 on this you should listen to it if you're a hip hop fan you're looking for another up-and-coming emcee looking for a new face and a few fantastic singles then get on this thing
